markerCategories: French & Indian War, Government & Politics, Government & Politics 19th Century, Invention, Military, Native American

markerText: So named from the blankets left by the Armstrong expedition after destroying Kittanning. Here also was a stopping point of the troops on en route to attack the Indians, Sept. 7, 1756.
streetAddress: US 422, .2 mile west of Blanket Hill Rd. (SR 2007), ~6 miles SE of Kittanning
markerCategories: French & Indian War, Military, Native American

markerText: Located near this point, 1839-73. Organized as the Great Western and later known as the Brady's Bend Iron Company. One of that era's largest iron works, and first to make iron rails west of the Alleghenies.
streetAddress: PA 68, just W of Queenstown Rd., ~1 mile NW of Allegheny River Bridge, East Brady

markerTitle: D. Leech & Company / Western Transportation Company
markerText: Operating at the Pa. Mainline Canal from 1829 to 1853, it was an integrated freight and passenger service using canalboats, wagons, railroads, and steamships. It was one of the most extensive and successful freight forwarding companies in Pa., connecting major cities and employing agents in at least ten states. The company partnered with the Pa. Railroad, providing agents and constructing new railroads for them. The boatbuilding yard was near here.
streetAddress: River Ave. & River Ave. (former canal right-of-way), Leechburg
markerCategories: Business & Industry, Canals, Railroads, Transportation, Navigation, Roads

markerText: Located on the nearby river bank, this outpost was built in June, 1779, and abandoned that autumn. It served the Brodhead expedition against the Senecas and was named for Maj. Gen. John Armstrong.
streetAddress: Water St. between Locust & McClarron overlooking Allegheny River, Manorville

markerText: In memory of General John Armstrong, a Scottish Covenanter and a soldier of the American Revolution. Lieutenant Colonel, 2d. Battalion Provincial troops 1756. Brigadier General Continental Army 1776. Major General Pennsylvania Militia 1778 to close of war. In command of Pennsylvania Militia at Brandywine and Germantown. Died 1795.
streetAddress: mounted on Armstrong Co. Courthouse at entrance, N end of Market St., Kittanning

markerText: The most notable Delaware Indian village west of the Alleghenies, was situated here from about 1730 until destroyed by Armstrong's expedition in 1756. Its name means "great river", applying to the Ohio-Allegheny.
streetAddress: Butler Rd. (Bus. Rt. 422) & Allegheny Ave., at Kittanning Citizens Bridge, Applewold
markerCategories: Early Settlement, French & Indian War, Military, Native American

markerText: The most notable Delaware Indian village west of the Alleghenies, was situated here from about 1730 until destroyed by Armstrong's expedition in 1756. Its name means "great river", applying to the Ohio-Allegheny.
streetAddress: US Bus. 422 (S Water Street), at PennDOT highway garage, SE end of Kittanning

markerTitle: Kittanning or Attique Indian Town - PLAQUE
markerText: ...Was located on this river flat. The chief settlement as early as 1727 of the Lenni-Lenape or Delaware Indians in their early westward movement from the Susquehanna River became the most important Indian center west of the Allegheny Mountains. Destroyed September 8, 1756 by Colonel John Armstrong and his 300 frontier troops from the Cumberland Valley.
streetAddress: At park on E bank of Allegheny River, at Kittaning Citizens Bridge, NW corner of N Water & Market St

markerText: A crusading journalist on Pittsburgh and New York newspapers, she won fame for her daring exploits and her investigations of social ills. In 1889-90, Bly circled the globe in 72 days. She was born Elizabeth Cochran and lived here as a child.
streetAddress: 500 Terrace Avenue, Apollo

markerText: A state-owned canal system, built 1826-34, to connect Philadelphia, Pittsburgh, and Erie. This 104-mile division ran from Johnstown to Pittsburgh and was part of the canal's mainline. In 1827, Dam #1 was constructed at Leechburg, and it supplied the remainder of the route to Pittsburgh with water and 7 miles of slack water navigation to Apollo, Pa. The dam remained in operation until 1865 and washed away in the Johnstown Flood of 1889.
streetAddress: park adjacent park adjacent to 476 Canal St., Leechburg

markerTitle: Pittsburgh Plate Glass Ford City Works
markerText: Among the largest and most productive plate glass factories in the world; opened 1887. At its peak, the plant employed more than 3,500 ethnically diverse workers, who passed through a specially-built tunnel under busy train tracks. Operations ended 1991.
streetAddress: Third Ave. at Ninth St., Ford City
markerCategories: Business & Industry, Ethnic & Immigration, Labor, Glass

markerText: A restored log church a few miles from here is a fine example of a pioneer place of worship. It memorializes the first Roman Catholic congregation in this region.
streetAddress: E Brady Rd. (PA 268) at SR 4007, Sugar Creek, ~4 miles NW of Cowansville

markerText: Formed March 12, 1800 from Washington and Allegheny counties. The county seat, Beaver, was laid out 1792-93. County's waterways have spurred its industrial growth. At Shippingport was the world's first full-scale atomic power station devoted to civilian needs.
streetAddress: County Courthouse, at park on 3rd St., Beaver
markerCategories: Business & Industry, Government & Politics, Government & Politics 19th Century, Transportation

markerText: The first U.S. military post north of the Ohio. Located on River Road and occupying the area between Bank, Insurance, and Market Streets. Built in 1778 and scene of Treaty of Fort McIntosh in 1785; also a survey base. Abandoned 1790-91.
streetAddress: 3rd St. (PA 68) at Insurance St., Beaver

markerText: On the plateau, southwest of this spot, was situated the camp of the army of General Anthony Wayne. This army, known as the Legion of the United States, encamped at this place when on the expedition against the Indians west of the Ohio, from November, 1792, until April, 1793. The expedition resulted in the Treaty of Greenvile, which was signed in the summer of 1795.
streetAddress: Duss Ave. (old PA 65) near Anthony Wayne Dr., N of Ambridge
markerCategories: Government & Politics 18th Century, Military, Native American

markerText: On this site are buried 594 members and workers of the Harmony Society, the people of Old Economy.
streetAddress: Church St. at cemetery, Ambridge

markerText: Constructed, 1828-1831, with bricks made by the Society members, this is the second building erected for worship. It is believed designed by Frederick Rapp. The spiritual life of the Society centered here.
streetAddress: Church St. near Creese St., Ambridge

markerText: During 64 years, "Ing-Rich" became one of the leading producers of porcelain enamel products in the U.S. Noted for durability, the company's output included outdoor advertising signs and "porcel panels" for building exteriors; it also made table tops, refrigerators & stove parts, and other products for the home. Founded here in 1901 by Louis Ingram & Ernest Richardson, it built plants in three other states. At its peak it employed over 1000 people.
streetAddress: 31st St. Ext. / Ing-Rich Rd/ near 24th St., Beaver Falls

markerText: Present Beaver perpetuates the name of a Delaware chief and of his village near here. Its location along the Ohio-Beaver River trails gave it importance in the fur trade.
streetAddress: Pa. 68 (3rd St.) at Wilson Ave., Beaver
markerCategories: Cities & Towns, Government & Politics, Government & Politics 18th Century, Native American

markerText: Gen. Anthony Wayne's army camped here Nov. 1792 to April 1793, preparing for the campaign which led to the Battle of Fallen Timbers with the Northwest Indians.
streetAddress: Duss Ave. at Anthony Wayne Dr., N of Ambridge
markerCategories: American Revolution, Cities & Towns, Military, Native American

markerText: One of the large Indian towns on the upper Ohio was located nearby in 1727-58. Important conferences were held here between the British, French, and Indians in the struggle for the Ohio Country.
streetAddress: Duss Ave. at Anthony Wayne Dr., N of Ambridge
markerCategories: Cities & Towns, Early Settlement, French & Indian War, Government & Politics, Government & Politics 18th Century, Native American

markerText: A short distance southeast of this spot, along the banks of the river, was situated the village of Logstown one of the largest Indian settlements on the upper Ohio. It was the scene of many important conferences between the French, the British and the Indians...
streetAddress: Duss Ave. (old PA 65) near Anthony Wayne Dr, N of Ambridge
markerCategories: Early Settlement, French & Indian War, Native American

markerText: Home of the noted state and national political leader is near here. He rose , between 1856-87, from local and state offices to U.S. Senator. A Republican Party leader from 1887 until his death in 1904.
streetAddress: 3rd St. (PA 68) at Insurance St., Beaver

markerTitle: NLRB v. Jones & Laughlin Supreme Court Ruling
markerText: In a landmark ruling on April 12, 1937, the U.S. Supreme Court upheld the constitutionality of the National Labor Relations Board v. Jones & Laughlin Steel Corp. The company had fired unionized workers at its Aliquippa plant here, but the court ordered their reinstatement and established workers' rights to organize and bargain collectively.
streetAddress: Franklin Ave. & Station St. (just below PA 51), Aliquippa

markerText: Third and last home, 1825-1905, of the Harmony Society, religious community founded by George Rapp in 1805. Administered by the Pennsylvania Historical and Museum Commission.
streetAddress: At site, 13th & Church Sts., Ambridge

markerText: Maintained by the Pennsylvania Historical and Museum Commission as a State memorial to the Harmony Society, organized February 15, 1805, dissolved December 15, 1905. These buildings erected 1824-1831, comprise a portion of the third settlement by the society. 1st Settlement - Harmony, Butler Co., Pa., 1804-15. 2nd Settlement - New Harmony, Posey Co., Ind., 1814-25. 3rd Settlement - Economy, Beaver Co., Pa., 1824-1905.
streetAddress: 13th St. at Ohio River Blvd (PA 65), at corner of site, Ambridge

markerText: Founded 1681 by William Penn as a Quaker Commonwealth. Birthplace of THE DECLARATION OF INDEPENDENCE and THE CONSTITUTION OF THE UNITED STATES.
streetAddress: US 30, .4 miles from PA/WV state line (MISSING)
markerCategories: Government & Politics, Government & Politics 17th Century, William Penn

markerText: Founded 1681 by William Penn as a Quaker Commonwealth. Birthplace of THE DECLARATION OF INDEPENDENCE and THE CONSTITUTION OF THE UNITED STATES.
streetAddress: PA 51 at PA/OH state line (MISSING)
markerCategories: Government & Politics, Government & Politics 17th Century, William Penn

markerText: Home of Grace Greenwood (Sara J. Clarke Lippincott, 1823-1904), pioneer woman correspondent, poetess and authoress. While living here during the mid-19th Century, she wrote many of her popular juvenile stories.
streetAddress: 1221 3rd Ave., New Brighton

markerText: A log structure, built prior to 1761, stood on this site. Known, also, as the Commandant's House; later as "Rising Sun Inn." Occupied by British officers until close of French and Indian War. Destroyed by fire, Dec. 14, 1885.
streetAddress: E. Pitt St. between Juliana & Richard Sts., Bedford
markerCategories: French & Indian War, Military, Houses & Homesteads

markerText: Built in 1815. East room housed the first bank in Bedford, known as the Allegheny Bank of Pennsylvania, from 1815 to 1832. Original vault can still be seen. Since 1924, used as public library and community centre.
streetAddress: E. Pitt St. between Juliana & Richard Sts., Bedford
markerCategories: Buildings & Architecture, Business & Industry, Houses & Homesteads

markerText: Formed on March 9, 1771 from Cumberland County, it first embraced most of western Pennsylvania. Named for its county seat (formerly Raystown) incorporated 1795. In 1758, Fort Bedford was erected here, and Forbes Road - to become a major highway west - was built.
streetAddress: Courthouse, S. Juliana & Penn Sts., Bedford
markerCategories: Forts, French & Indian War, Government & Politics, Government & Politics 18th Century, Roads

markerText: Medicinal values of these springs discovered about 1796. It soon became a leading resort visited by numerous notables. James Buchanan used the Springs as his summer White House while President.
streetAddress: Business US 220 at resort, Bedford Springs
markerCategories: Business & Industry, Cities & Towns, Government & Politics 19th Century, Science & Medicine

markerText: Settled about 1750, known then as Raystown. Site of an early trade post and Fort Bedford, 1758. Base for Forbes, Bouquet expeditions. In 1794 Washington here reviewed forces in Whiskey Rebellion.
streetAddress: 651 E Pitt St. near Bus. 30, just E of Bedford
markerCategories: Early Settlement, Forts, French & Indian War, George Washington, Military, Whiskey Rebellion

markerText: Settled about 1750, known then as Raystown. Site of an early trade post and Fort Bedford, 1758. Base for Forbes, Bouquet expeditions. In 1794 Washington here reviewed forces in Whiskey Rebellion.
streetAddress: Bus. 30 near Rt. 220 intersection, at Fairgrounds entrance (& Coffee Pot), W side of Bedford
markerCategories: Forts, French & Indian War, George Washington, Whiskey Rebellion

markerText: Settled about 1750, known then as Raystown. Site of an early trade post and Fort Bedford, 1758. Base for Forbes, Bouquet expeditions. In 1794 Washington here reviewed forces in Whiskey Rebellion.
streetAddress: N Richard St. (Bus. Rt. 220), N end of Bedford, ~.3 miles from river
markerCategories: Forts, French & Indian War, George Washington, Whiskey Rebellion

markerTitle: The Beginning of Agricultural Cooperative Extension Service
markerText: One of the nation's earliest cooperative extension offices was established in 1910 in Schellsburg, Bedford County with A. B. Ross as county agent. The innovative program sought to educate farmers about agricultural science to increase their productivity. County Extension offices are now found throughout the US. Farmers and other citizens continue to benefit from agents' expertise on agriculture, 4-H programs, and family and consumer science.
streetAddress: 3744 Pitt St. (Rt. 30), Schellsburg (next to bank)
markerCategories: Agriculture, Education, Government & Politics 20th Century, Professions & Vocations

markerText: Before and during the Civil War, Benjamin Walker, Abner Walker, Sr. and George Harbaugh worked closely with African American Underground Railroad conductors John Fiddler, Elisa Rouse and Joseph Crawley. Hundreds of fugitive slaves were led from the PA border through Bedford County via the Walker Homestead, across the mountain and north to freedom. Participation in the UGRR was dangerous, due to the proximity to the MD border.
streetAddress: Rainbow Dr., at Beutman Rd., Alum Bank, 1.5 mi. NW of Pleasantville
markerCategories: African American, Civil War, Underground Railroad

markerText: This inn at the junction of the Forbes and Burd Roads was operated, 1779-1815, by Jean Bonnet and his heirs. In mid-1794, during the Whiskey Rebellion, embattled farmers met here and raised a liberty pole to protest the federal excise tax on whiskey. That October, troops called by President Washington camped here on their march west to quell the insurrection.
streetAddress: Jct. of Lincoln Hwy. (US 30) & Allegheny Rd. (PA 31), ~4 miles NW of Bedford
markerCategories: George Washington, Inns & Taverns, Military, Whiskey Rebellion

markerText: Graves of ten of Capt. Phillips' militia killed by Indians, July 16, 1780. (Administered by the Pennsylvania Historical and Museum Commission.) - blued out due to no longer administered by PHMC
streetAddress: At site at deadend of Capt. Phillip's Meml. Rd., off PA 26, 4 miles NW of Saxton

markerText: Built about 1771. It was the headquarters of George Washington in October, 1794, when he came to Bedford to review troops assembled here to quell Whiskey Rebellion in western part of the State.
streetAddress: E. Pitt St. between Juliana & Richard Sts., Bedford
markerCategories: American Revolution, George Washington, Military, Whiskey Rebellion, Houses & Homesteads

markerText: Near here was located Shawnee Cabins camp. Used by Gen. Forbes army in the campaign of 1758 against the French at Fort Duquesne in present Pittsburgh.
streetAddress: US 30 near Graham Ave., W of Schellsburg

markerText: This intersection marks the point where Forbes Road of 1758 diverged from the path cut by Col. Burd in 1755. The Forbes Road led through the wilderness west toward Ligonier from this point.
streetAddress: Jct. Lincoln Hwy. (US 30) & Allegheny Rd.) PA 31, ~4 miles W of Bedford

markerText: ... of the Allegheny Mountains. At this point the Forbes Road leads northward to Fort Dewart. 15 miles from Fort Bedford.
streetAddress: Rt. 30, at curve opposite Old Shot Factory, just E of Somerset Co. line

markerText: Near this site on July 30, 1758, Cols. Bouquet and Washington discussed proposed routes by which Gen. Forbes' army would attack French Ft. Duquesne. Bouquet preferred the route due west from Bedford, while Washington advocated Braddock's 1755 road to the south. Forbes himself chose the route from Bedford, and as a result occupied the ruins of Ft. Duquesne on Nov. 25, 1758. Forbes Road encouraged subsequent westward expansion through Pa.
streetAddress: Bedford Valley Rd. (Rt. 220) near Providence Lutheran Church, 2 miles N of Centerville
markerCategories: French & Indian War, George Washington, Military, Roads

markerText: At the Juniata Crossings, half a mile north of here, General Forbes erected a small stockade in 1758 to protect the communications of his army moving west to attack Fort Duquesne.
streetAddress: US 30, 2 miles W of Breezewood
markerCategories: French & Indian War, Military, Transportation, Roads

markerTitle: Forbes Road, 1758, Fort Bedford to Fort Duquesne - Fort Bedford-Raystown (PLAQUE)
markerText: Depot of supplies assembling place of an army of nearly eight thousand men and the starting point of General John Forbes' Expedition for the possession of Fort Duquesne. The road leads Westward to the Forks.
streetAddress: On wall at NW corner Pitt & Juliana Sts., Bedford
markerCategories: Forts, French & Indian War, Military, Roads

markerTitle: Forbes Road, 1758, Fort Bedford to Fort Duquesne - Fort Dewart McLeans' Encampment (PLAQUE)
markerText: Built by Colonel Henry Bouquet and Garrisoned for several years. The Forbes Road leads Westward to Edmond's Swamp, 17 miles from Fort Bedford
streetAddress: Off US 30, on private property accessed via Fort Duart(Dewart) Rd.
markerCategories: Forts, French & Indian War, Military, Roads

markerTitle: Forbes Road, 1758, Fort Bedford to Fort Duquesne - Shawnee Cabins Encampment (PLAQUE)
markerText: At this point the Forbes Road leads Southwestward to the Eastern Slope of the Allegheny Mountains, 8 1/2 miles from Fort Bedford.
streetAddress: US 30 at W edge of Schellsburg

markerTitle: Forbes Road, 1758, Fort Bedford to Fort Duquesne - The Forks (PLAQUE)
markerText: And the road cut by Colonel James Burd, in 1755, and the Forbes Road diverge here. Forbes Road leading Southwestward to Shawnee Cabins Encampment 4 1/2 miles from Fort Bedford.
streetAddress: Junction Lincoln Hwy. (US 30) & Allegheny Rd. (PA 31), ~4 miles W of Bedford

markerText: First known as Raystown and built during the summer of 1758 by the forces of Col. Henry Bouquet, the fort was the rendezvous from which the expedition of Gen. Forbes advanced to occupy Fort Duquesne (Pittsburgh). Museum stands on the original site.
streetAddress: Fort Bedford Dr., across from museum entrance, Bedford

markerText: Site of lots on which John Fraser and his wife established an inn and trading post in 1758. Fraser had been a guide and interpreter for Colonel Washington. The inn provided meals for army officers at Fort Raystown (Bedford).
streetAddress: NE corner E. Pitt/Lincoln Hwy. (Bus. 30) & Richard Sts., Bedford
markerCategories: Buildings & Architecture, Business & Industry, George Washington, Inns & Taverns

markerText: Entrenchments still visible by the roadsides were prepared in June, 1863, by militia under Col. J.C. Higgins against threatened Confederate attack toward the railroad at Altoona. The march of troops toward Gettysburg on June 30 - July 1 ended the danger and the need for these defenses.
streetAddress: Church View Rd., SR 1005 (former PA 36 & LR 286) at State Game Lands, 5 miles S of Loysburg

markerText: On land granted by John Schell for the purpose of erecting a union church, construction of this primitive log church building was begun in 1806 by the Reformed and Lutheran Congregations of this area.
streetAddress: Lincoln Hwy. (US 30), near Cemetery Rd., just W of Schellsburg

markerText: Founded 1681 by William Penn as a Quaker Commonwealth. Birthplace of THE DECLARATION OF INDEPENDENCE and THE CONSTITUTION OF THE UNITED STATES.
streetAddress: PA 96, 1000 ft. from state line
markerCategories: Government & Politics, Government & Politics 17th Century, William Penn

markerText: Founded 1681 by William Penn as a Quaker Commonwealth. Birthplace of THE DECLARATION OF INDEPENDENCE and THE CONSTITUTION OF THE UNITED STATES.
streetAddress: US 220 , 1650 feet from state line
markerCategories: Government & Politics, Government & Politics 17th Century, William Penn

markerText: This is one of the original service plazas for the nation's first long-distance superhighway. On October 1, 1940, the Turnpike opened, stretching 160 miles from Irwin to Carlisle. The Turnpike Commission had been created in 1937; construction utilized the old South Pennsylvania Railroad's right-of-way and tunnels. By 1957 the Turnpike spanned 360 miles across the State and extended 110 miles north to Scranton.
streetAddress: South Midway Service Plaza, just E of Turnpike Exit 11, Bedford

markerText: This is one of the original service plazas for the nation's first long-distance superhighway. On October 1, 1940, the Turnpike opened, stretching 160 miles from Irwin to Carlisle. The Turnpike Commission had been created in 1937; construction utilized the old South Pennsylvania Railroad's right-of-way and tunnels. By 1957 the Turnpike spanned 360 miles across the State and extended 110 miles north to Scranton.
streetAddress: North Midway Service Plaza, just E of Turnpike Exit 11, Bedford

markerText: Capt. William Phillips and 11 men of his militia company were captured near this point by Indians, July 16, 1780. Ten men were killed here and were buried later by a search party. Capt. Phillips and son Elijah, taken prisoner, were freed by British at end of Revolution.
streetAddress: Raystown Rd. (PA 26) at Capt. Phillips Monument Rd., 4 miles NW of Saxton

markerText: In 1936 seventy-five percent of Pennsylvania farms had no electric service. During the next five years, with Federal support, 14 consumer-owned cooperatives were formed in this State. Bedford Rural Electric Cooperative, which serves members in Bedford, Fulton and Somerset counties, was incorporated on June 2, 1939.
streetAddress: E Pitt St. / Lincoln Hwy. (SR 4010 / Bus. 30) between Donohue Manor & Clark Bldg. Rds., .5 mile E of

markerText: In 1936 seventy-five percent of Pennsylvania farms had no electric service. Over the next five years, in response to their needs, 14 consumer-owned cooperatives were formed in this State. Serving users in Bedford, Fulton and Huntingdon counties, New Enterprise Rural Electric Cooperative was incorporated November 18, 1938.
streetAddress: PA 869 near Chestnut St. at Co-op HQ, New Enterprise

markerText: This house, built in 1816 by the Hon. James Russell, first burgess of Bedford, is considered a fine example of Georgian style of the Post-Colonial period.
streetAddress: 203 S. Juliana St., Bedford
markerCategories: Buildings & Architecture, Government & Politics, Government & Politics 19th Century, Houses & Homesteads

markerText: A village site nearby on the Raystown Path. Named for a group of Shawnee Indians who halted here on their retreat from the Potomac to the lower Allegheny valley in the early 18th century.
streetAddress: US 30 near Mill Rd., W of Schellsburg
markerCategories: Early Settlement, Native American, Paths & Trails

markerText: Set aside, at the time of Manor survey in 1761, by the family of William Penn, as property of the town of Bedford.
streetAddress: S. Juliana St. at W Penn St., Bedford
markerCategories: Government & Politics, Government & Politics 18th Century, William Penn

markerText: Polish pioneer, Indian trader, settled along Schuylkill River in this area, 1712. He served the Provincial Government as a messenger-interpreter during negotiations with Indian tribes in 1728. He was buried, 1736, in graveyard of St. Gabriel's Church.
streetAddress: US 422 eastbound, at St. Gabriel's Church and graveyard, Douglassville
markerCategories: Early Settlement, Ethnic & Immigration, Government & Politics, Government & Politics 18th Century, Native American

markerText: Doctor Spencer Baird, noted naturalist, was born in this house in 1823. He organized U.S. Geological Survey, 1879; was U.S. Commissioner of Fisheries, 1871-1887; Secretary, Smithsonian Institution, 1878-1887. Died in Mass., 1887.
streetAddress: 5th & Washington Sts., SW corner, Reading (Missing)

markerText: Born in Reading, this self-taught artist won international recognition for his paintings of barnyard and woodland creatures, still lifes, and landscapes. He was the creator of the famed Bon Ami chick. Ben Austrian had studios in Paris and Florida and at Mount Penn, but the place he loved most was "Clovelly-at-the-Pinnacle" nearby, where he died at the age of fifty-one. The artist is buried here.
streetAddress: at New Bethel Union Church Cemetery, New Bethel Church Rd., RD 2, Kempton

markerText: Formed March 11, 1752 from parts of Chester, Lancaster and Philadelphia counties. Named for Berkshire, England. The county seat of Reading was made a borough in 1783 and a city in 1847. County's early iron works gave rise to Pennsylvania's iron industry.
streetAddress: Courthouse, N. 6th & Court Sts., Reading
markerCategories: Government & Politics, Government & Politics 18th Century, Iron & Steel

markerText: Berks County's oldest Black church building. Erected 1837 by free African Americans; became an Underground Railroad station for escaped slaves seeking freedom. Rebuilt 1867; remodeled 1889. Congregation, dating from 1822, moved to Windsor Street in 1974.
streetAddress: 119 N. 10th St., Reading
markerCategories: African American, Buildings & Architecture, Religion, Underground Railroad

markerText: Established here in 1893 by C.A. Mory and Associates, it was among the largest casket manufacturers in the world and earliest traded on the N.Y. and Phila. stock exchanges. Â The company secured numerous patents for innovative improvements and designs and was renowned for its fine craftsmanship. Progressive marketing techniques led to international sales. After the company's sale in 1987 and closure in 1988, the factory was demolished.
streetAddress: 23 N Walnut St., Boyertown, near Philadelphia Ave. and Walnut Woods Retirement Community

markerText: Aviation pioneer Spaatz was a 1914 graduate of West Point and a pilot in France in World War I. He rose to the rank of brigadier general in 1940 and general in 1945. During World War II he commanded the US 8th Air Force and the US Strategic Air Forces in Europe, facilitating the ground invasion and liberation of western Europe. He was first Chief of Staff of the newly independent US Air Force, 1947-48. Boyertown was his home.
streetAddress: PA 562 (S Reading Ave.) at W 2nd St., Boyertown

markerText: Erected 1749; once owned by Baron Stiegel. Operated by ironmaster George Ege, 1774-1824. Hessians were employed in Revolutionary days to cut a rock channel for water supply. Site is to the north of Womelsdorf.
streetAddress: Conrad Weiser Pkwy. (US 422) at N Water St., Womelsdorf
markerCategories: American Revolution, Buildings & Architecture, Business & Industry, Iron & Steel, Professions & Vocations

markerText: Organized 1729, this is one of the early Lutheran churches founded by Rev. John Caspar Stoever, Jr., who started the parish records in 1730. A log church, erected before 1749, was replaced by the present stone building in 1809. Since 1853, Lutheran and Reformed services have been held here.
streetAddress: Christmas Village Rd. (SR4010) at Groff Rd., SW of Bernville

markerText: Established on Iron Stone Creek, one half mile to the east, by James Lewis, Anthony Morris, Thomas Potts, and Thomas Rutter. Called after Colebrookdale Furnace in England, it is considered the first blast furnace to be erected in Pennsylvania, c. 1720.
streetAddress: S Reading Ave. (PA 562) near Farmington Ave. (SR2040) SW of Boyertown

markerText: Pioneer Indian interpreter, treaty maker, 1732-1760. The Indians called him the "Holder of the Heavens." He lived, died, and is buried on this property, now a State Park devoted to his memory.
streetAddress: US 422 eastbound, at Weiser Homestead, E of Womelsdorf
markerCategories: Early Settlement, Government & Politics, Native American

markerText: A hewn-log building, erected on this site about 1750; operated until 1760 by Conrad Weiser, distinguished pioneer settler, treaty maker, Indian agent and interpreter, and first Berks county lay judge.
streetAddress: 505 Penn St., Penn Sq., Reading
markerCategories: Buildings & Architecture, Early Settlement, Government & Politics, Native American, Professions & Vocations

markerText: Greatest American pioneer and wilderness scout. Born Nov. 2, 1734. Spent the first 16 years of his life on the Boone Homestead a few miles north. Now a State historical shrine dedicated to American youth.
streetAddress: Ben Franklin Hwy. (US 422) westbound near Daniel Boone Rd., just SE of Baumstown

markerText: Greatest American pioneer and wilderness scout. Born Nov. 2, 1734. Spent the first 16 years of his life on the Boone Homestead a few miles north. Now a State historical shrine dedicated to American youth.
streetAddress: US 422 eastbound, just W of S Baumstown Rd., at Baumstown Union Sunday School

markerText: Famous pioneer and wilderness scout, who lived in this area his first 16 years. Born 3 miles northwest on site of Daniel Boone Homestead, State historical shrine.
streetAddress: Benj. Franklin Hwy. (US 422) eastbound between Baumstown and Douglassville

markerText: Site of the birthplace of Daniel Boone on Nov.2, 1734, and his home until 1750. Administered by the Pennsylvania Historical and Museum Commission.
streetAddress: at site, Daniel Boone Rd. (SR 2041) at Old Daniel Boone Rd., N of Baumstown
markerCategories: Buildings & Architecture, Early Settlement, Houses & Homesteads

markerText: Built 1745 by Dr. George de Benneville, preacher in this area 1743-55, and founder of Universalism in America. He died in Philadelphia in 1793. The house is 2.25 miles away on a side road.
streetAddress: Memorial Hwy. (PA 622) at Blacksmith Rd., 1.5 miles N of Yellow House

markerText: Built in 1767 by John de Turk, son of Isaac de Turk, a Huguenot who settled here in 1712 and was one of a number of French Protestants who were pioneers in this part of Berks County.
streetAddress: Junction DeTurk Rd. & Memorial Hwy. (PA 73/662), 1/2 mile S of Oley

markerText: On this site was the house occupied by Dr. Jonathan Potts; Deputy Director General, 1777-1780, of Northern and Middle Departments of the Continental Army.
streetAddress: 545 Penn St. (near 6th St. intersection), Reading

markerText: Site of the home of Dr. Bodo Otto, Military Surgeon in Continental Army, 1775-82. Served as Surgeon-in-Chief at Valley Forge, 1777-78; Physician and Surgeon of the Continental Hospitals. Died, 1787.
streetAddress: 525 Penn St., Penn Sq., Reading
markerCategories: American Revolution, Military, Professions & Vocations, Science & Medicine

markerText: Named in honor of Charles E. Duryea, inventor and builder of first successful hill-climbing gasoline automobile in U.S. Duryea Drive, extending from City Park to the Pagoda, is the course used by Duryea for testing his cars, 1900-1907.
streetAddress: Clymer St., just N of Hill Rd. & Constitution Blvd. and just S of Duryea Dr., Reading
markerCategories: Business & Industry, Invention, Oil & Gas, Professions & Vocations, Transportation

markerText: Established 1725 as Oley; name changed to Exeter, 1742. Present stone meeting house built 1759 near site of two previous log structures. Buried here are members of the Boone, Ellis, Hughes, Lee, and Lincoln families. Meetings discontinued 1899; building reopened for worship in 1949.
streetAddress: Meetinghouse Rd. & Boone Rd., .5 mile S of PA 562 & 2 mile W of Yellow House

markerText: Site of Federal Inn, erected about 1754. George Washington, with military escort, was a guest here, October, 1794, when on his way to muster an armed force to suppress the Whiskey Rebellion.
streetAddress: 445 Penn St., Penn Sq., Reading
markerCategories: Buildings & Architecture, Business & Industry, George Washington, Inns & Taverns, Military, Whiskey Rebellion

markerText: This home, built 1801 by Henry Fisher, is a fine example of late Georgian architecture. Brought from the British Isles, this style is reflected in old homes of eastern and southern Pennsylvania.
streetAddress: Memorial Hwy. (PA 622), 1.4 miles N of Yellow House

markerText: Established in 1909 by Harry C. Urich, the firm designed and fabricated custom auto bodies for the finest domestic and foreign automobile manufacturers, notably Cadillac, Duesenberg, Packard, Mercedes-Benz, ALCO, SGV, and Rolls-Royce. It was purchased by General Motors subsidiary Fisher Body Co. in 1925, and in 1930, GM moved fabrication operations to Detroit. The Fleetwood name was used by Cadillac for its luxury cars for another 60 years.
streetAddress: NE corner of N Richmind & Locust Sts., Fleetwood

markerText: Built 1756; garrisoned during the French and Indian War by troops under Capt. Christian Busse. Pennsylvania's major frontier defense east of Ft. Augusta (Sunbury). The site is 3/4 mile to the northwest.
streetAddress: Lancaster Ave. (PA 501) at Ft. Henry Rd., 2 miles N of Bethel

markerText: Re-named Bally for Father Augustin Bally. The third Roman Catholic mission and first Catholic school in the State were established here in 1743 by Father Theodore Schneider.
streetAddress: Main St. (PA 100), at 7th St., Bally (next to bank)

markerText: Founded in 1934 by Rosalie Edge, it is the world's first refuge for birds of prey. It had been a popular shooting site because of its location on a major hawk migration corridor and a 1929 bounty placed on northern goshawks. Through the work of its founder and early supporters, such as Richard Pough, it became a raptor conservation research, education, and training facility and a hawk-watching destination for bird and nature lovers globally.
streetAddress: Hawk Mtn. Rd., at path to north lookout
markerCategories: Education, Environment, Science & Medicine, Sports & Recreation, Women

markerText: Pastor of the Trinity Lutheran Church from 1803 to 1829; Member of Congress, 1829-38; first U.S. Minister to Austria; Candidate for governor of Pennsylvania at the time of death in 1844. His home was on this site.
streetAddress: 400 Penn St. (at S 4th), Reading

markerText: Established by Thomas Maybury in 1745 on the west bank of the Perkiomen Creek for the purpose of manufacturing iron. Maybury is credited with producing here in 1767 the first cast-iron cooking-stove in North America.
streetAddress: Chestnut St (PA 29/100), just N of Gravel Pike/Seisholtzville Rd. intersection, Hereford

markerText: After Burgoyne's surrender, 1777, German mercenaries, mostly Hessian, were held prisoners at various places until end of war. Those brought to Reading, 1781, were encamped until 1783 in huts on the hillside a quarter-mile to the north.
streetAddress: Mineral Spring Rd. (Bus. US422 westbound) just E of Hessian Rd., Reading

markerText: Site of house occupied by Joseph Hiester from about 1792 until his death, 1832; a Lt. Col. in Continental Army; Delegate to Provincial Convention in 1776; Member of Congress for 14 years; Governor of Pennsylvania, 1820-23.
streetAddress: 439 Penn St., Penn Sq., Reading
markerCategories: American Revolution, Government & Politics, Governors, Military, Houses & Homesteads

markerText: Hopewell Forge, 1744, and Furnace, 1770, were seven miles south. The furnace and the remains of an iron making community of the era are administered by the National Park Service, with recreation areas.
streetAddress: Perkiomen Ave. (US 422) westbound just E of S Center Rd. (PA 345), Baumstown

markerText: Hopewell Forge, 1744, and Furnace, 1770, were seven miles south. The furnace and the remains of an iron making community of the era are administered by the National Park Service, with recreation areas.
streetAddress: S Baumstown Rd. (US 422) eastbound at S Center Rd. (PA 345), near Pioneer Crossing Landfill, Baumsto

markerText: Born here March 21, 1857. A graduate of West Point, 1879. He held commands in the Philippines, 1899-1901 and 1915-17, and rose to the rank of Lt. Gen in 1918. On Oct. 16, 1918, he succeeded Gen. Pershing as head of the American First Army in Europe. Died, San Francisco, 1935.
streetAddress: 145 S. 6th St. at Chestnut, Reading

markerText: Labor leader and advocate for child labor reform, pensions, and the state's first workers' compensation act. Self-educated, Maurer was elected president of the Penn-sylvania Federation of Labor from 1912-1928. He served as state legislator from Reading as a Socialist (1910-1918). He ran unsuccessfully for vice president of the United States on the Socialist ticket in 1928 and 1932. He was a lifelong Reading resident.
streetAddress: Heritage Park near Workers' Memorial, 6th & Canal Sts., Reading

markerText: The evolution of the business located here mirrors America's changing transportation scene. In the factory begun by Mr. Sweinhart in 1872, horse-drawn carriages, farm and delivery vehicles, and sleighs were built. After 1914, bus and truck bodies, and other commercial and military vehicles, were made here. Production ceased, 1990, but the original 1872 shop became part of the Boyertown Museum of Historic Vehicles.
streetAddress: 3rd. & Walnut Sts., Boyertown
markerCategories: Agriculture, Business & Industry, Entrepreneurs, Military, Transportation

markerText: Governor of Pennsylvania, 1823-1829. Born, 1775, in the old parsonage behind Christ Lutheran Church. During his terms, the State inaugurated its extensive program of internal improvements. He died at Lancaster in 1852.
streetAddress: Conrad Weiser Pkwy. (US 422) at Main St. & Longs Church Ln., outside Stouchsburg
markerCategories: Government & Politics, Government & Politics 19th Century, Governors

markerText: Revolutionary soldier, Congressman, Governor 1820-1823, lived in the Hiester Mansion. Now a part of the Berks County Welfare Farm.
streetAddress: Bernville Rd. (PA 183) at Upper Van Reed Rd., near Leinbachs
markerCategories: American Revolution, Government & Politics, Governors, Mansions & Manors, Military

markerText: President Lincoln's great-great grand-father Mordecai purchased Andrew Robeson's land and built the stone house that stands about 1 1/4 miles south of here in 1733. Mordecai Lincoln served as Justice of the Peace of Philadelphia County from 1733 to 1736, and was a friend and colleague of George Boone Jr., uncle of the pioneer Daniel Boone. Abraham Lincoln referred to his ancestors from Berks County, Pennsylvania in letters.
streetAddress: 5700 Perkiomen Ave. (US 422), near Lincoln Rd., Reading / Exeter Twp.
markerCategories: Abraham Lincoln, Early Settlement, Government & Politics 18th Century, Houses & Homesteads

markerText: The first organized Amish Mennonite congregation in America. Established by 1740. Disbanded following Indian attack, September 29, 1757, in which a Provincial soldier and three members of the Jacob Hochstetler family were killed near this point.
streetAddress: Old US 22, 1 mile W of Shartlesville

markerText: A building erected about 1748 by Moravians, for use as a church and school, stands on the side road, about 1.5 miles away. Here they conducted a boarding school, 1745-51; and built a later schoolhouse, since demolished, in 1776.
streetAddress: Memorial Hwy. (PA 622), near Mine Ln., ~1 mile S of Oley

markerText: Given in common to the citizens of Reading, in 1748, by the family of William Penn.
streetAddress: Perkiomen Ave. (Business U.S. 422 westbound), near 11th & Penn intersection, Reading
markerCategories: Government & Politics, Government & Politics 18th Century, William Penn

markerText: "Pilgrim's Rest" was the name given to this spring on the Tulpehocken Path by Count Zinzendorf, the Moravian missionary, on his journey to the Indian towns of Shamokin and Wyoming in 1742.
streetAddress: Bethel Rd. (PA 501) at Pilger Ruh Rd., N of Bethel near Schuylkill Co. line
markerCategories: Environment, Native American, Religion, Paths & Trails

markerText: Laid out 1748 by direction of Thomas Penn. Seat of Berks County since 1752. Incorporated borough, 1783. Soon became, and has remained, center of the Pennsylvania-Dutch area. An old and progressive industrial community.
streetAddress: Lancaster Ave. (Bus. 222) at Summit Ave., S end of city
markerCategories: Business & Industry, Cities & Towns, Early Settlement, Ethnic & Immigration, Government & Politics

markerText: Laid out 1748 by direction of Thomas Penn. Seat of Berks County since 1752. Incorporated borough, 1783. Soon became, and has remained, center of the Pennsylvania-Dutch area. An old and progressive industrial community.
streetAddress: US 122 S
markerCategories: Business & Industry, Cities & Towns, Early Settlement, Ethnic & Immigration, Government & Politics

markerText: Laid out 1748 by direction of Thomas Penn. Seat of Berks County since 1752. Incorporated borough, 1783. Soon became, and has remained, center of the Pennsylvania-Dutch area. An old and progressive industrial community.
streetAddress: US 122 N
markerCategories: Business & Industry, Cities & Towns, Early Settlement, Ethnic & Immigration, Government & Politics

markerText: Laid out 1748 by direction of Thomas Penn. Seat of Berks County since 1752. Incorporated borough, 1783. Soon became, and has remained, center of the Pennsylvania-Dutch area. An old and progressive industrial community.
streetAddress: Penn Ave. (Bus. Rt. 422) just W of Ben Franklin Hwy. / Conrad Weiser Pkwy. (Rt. 422) cloverleaf
markerCategories: Business & Industry, Cities & Towns, Ethnic & Immigration

markerText: Laid out 1748 by direction of Thomas Penn. Seat of Berks County since 1752. Incorporated borough, 1783. Soon became, and has remained, center of the Pennsylvania-Dutch area. An old and progressive industrial community.
streetAddress: N 5th St. Hwy. / Allentown Pike (US 222) at N city line, just S of Warren St. Bypass (PA 12)
markerCategories: Business & Industry, Cities & Towns, Early Settlement, Ethnic & Immigration, Government & Politics

markerText: In 1877, amidst hard times, unrest hit U.S. rail lines. Workers for the Reading Railroad had endured pay cuts. Here, on July 23, militia fired into an unarmed crowd that blocked the trains, and 10 people were killed. U.S. troops reopened the railroad.
streetAddress: 7th & Penn Sts., Reading

markerText: A disastrous fire destroyed the theater that stood at Philadelphia Ave. & Washington St. on Jan. 13, 1908. It claimed 170 victims, many buried here, due to overcrowding, poorly designed and unmarked exits, and inadequate fire escapes. The tragedy prompted the Pa. General Assembly to enact fire safety laws and improve construction and inspection standards, making public buildings safer and influencing similar legislation in other states.
streetAddress: Fairview Cemetery, north side of W Philadelphia Ave., Boyertown

markerText: Founded 1794 as Reading Furnace by ironmaster George Ege. In 1845 Henry P. Robeson expanded the furnace, spurring establishment in 1855 of the town of Robesonia. Although the furnace itself ceased operation and was razed in 1927, the Georgian-style ironmaster's mansion, Italianate office building, workers' houses, and other structures survived. The district is located one mile south of here.
streetAddress: US 422 (Penn Ave.) at S Freeman St., E end of Robesonia, in front of bank
markerCategories: Buildings & Architecture, Business & Industry, Furnaces, Iron & Steel, Professions & Vocations

markerText: Regarded best example of Skew Bridge in U.S. Designed by Richard Osborn for the P & R Railroad in 1857. Each course of the arch of 40 feet is laid in ellipsoidal curve, each stone properly curved. There is no keystone.
streetAddress: N. 6th St. at railroad bridge, near Woodward St., Reading

markerText: Founder of the family-owned department store chain. An immigrant from Russia, 1911, he came to Reading as a peddler. His first store began here after WWI and gradually expanded. New stores opened starting in 1962. In 1969 he died; thirty years later, Boscov's had 34 stores in five states.
streetAddress: 1400 Block N. 9th St. at Pike St., Reading

markerText: First European settlers in present Berks County on land granted by William Penn, 1704-5. The home of Mounce and Ingeborg Jones, built 1716 and the oldest house in the county, stands at the opposite end of the river bridge.
streetAddress: E Main St. / W Schuylkill Rd. (PA 724) between River Bridge Rd. and Red Corner Rd., 4.2 miles SE of
markerCategories: Early Settlement, Ethnic & Immigration, William Penn, Houses & Homesteads

markerText: Member of the Continental Congress, a Revolutionary soldier, first Pennsylvania governor, 1790-99, lived at his estate Angelica from 1774 to 1794. The Berks County Farm and Home now occupies the site.
streetAddress: E. Lancaster Ave. (US 222) at Mifflin Blvd., at corner of school campus, Shillington
markerCategories: American Revolution, Government & Politics, Government & Politics 18th Century, Governors, Military

markerText: Pioneer ironmaster and opponent of slavery who died 1730. Built Pennsylvania's first ironworks nearby, 1716. In ensuing decade he erected Pine Forge and built this mansion; in 19th century it was an Underground Railroad stop. Academy was founded here, 1945.
streetAddress: Pine Forge Rd. (SR 2063) at Pine Forge Academy, Pine Forge
markerCategories: African American, Business & Industry, Education, Iron & Steel, Mansions & Manors, Professions & Vocations, Underground Railroad

markerTitle: Thompson's Rifle Battalion: Capt. George Nagel's Company
markerText: With men enlisted from Berks County, Nagel's Company was a part of the first battalion in the colonies authorized by Congress, in June 1775. After gathering at Reading the following month, this company and other companies of the battalion marched approximately 350 miles in order to join the American siege of Boston.
streetAddress: 940 Centre Ave. (PA 61) near Spring St., Greenfield Manor section of Reading

markerText: An Indian path from Shamokin (Sunbury) came over the mts. by way of Klingerstown and Pine Grove to Weiser's place in the Tulpehocken Valley. Chiefs of the Six Nations, carrying "words of wampum" to Brother Onas (Penn) at Philadelphia, traveled this path.
streetAddress: Conrad Weiser Pkwy. / W Penn Ave. (US 422), at Conrad Weiser Homestead E of Womelsdorf
markerCategories: Government & Politics, Native American, Transportation, William Penn, Paths & Trails

markerText: An Indian path connecting the Iroquois capital at Shamokin, now Sunbury, with the Tulpehocken Valley, ran northwest through here. It was used by ambassadors to "Brother Onas," i.e., Wm. Penn and his successors.
streetAddress: Lancaster Ave. (PA 501) at Schubert Rd., just N of I-78/US22), 1 mile N of Bethel
markerCategories: Forts, French & Indian War, Military, Native American, Paths & Trails

markerText: This canal was operated from 1828-1884. It connected the Schuylkill at Reading with the Susquehanna at Middletown. Remains of tow path can be seen .3 mile southeast of here, along the Tulpehocken Creek.
streetAddress: Upper Van Reed Rd. near Tulpehocken Creek, ~1 mile S of Leinbachs
markerCategories: Business & Industry, Canals, Transportation, Mills, Navigation

markerText: The canal, at this point, followed the north bank of the Tulpehocken. A dam, two locks, and a mule bridge made it possible for boats to cross Northkill Creek. Nearby were grist mills, a lime kiln, and a tannery.
streetAddress: PA 183 & N Heidelberg Rd., just SE of Bernville
markerCategories: Business & Industry, Canals, Transportation, Mills, Navigation

markerText: In use, 1828-1884. It connected the Schuylkill at Reading with the Susquehanna at Middletown. About a mile east, at tip of Fritts Island, are remains of easternmost lock. It passed boats traveling to and from Philadelphia by way of Schuylkill Navigation.
streetAddress: Morgantown Rd. (PA 10) & Philadelphia Ave. (PA 724), 2 miles S of Reading
markerCategories: Business & Industry, Canals, Transportation, Mills, Navigation

markerText: A major 20th century American poet, Stevens was awarded the Pulitzer Prize for his "Collected Poems" in 1955. Works such as "Bantams in Pinewoods," "Harmonium," and "The Auroras of Autumn" combined poetic language with serious philosophical ideas. His birthplace was here.
streetAddress: 323 N 5th St., Reading

markerTitle: William Penn - First Visit to America - PLAQUE
markerText: William Penn, on his first visit to America 1682-1684, came farthest north on Schuylkill River fifty miles up from the falls of Schuylkill to or near the mouth of Monocacy Creek three fourths of a mile south-west of this marker.
streetAddress: US 422, .8 mile SE of Baumstown (264 E Ben Franklin Hwy., Birdsboro)

markerText: Eminent jurist; Member State Supreme Court, 1857-1868; Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of U.S., 1870-80; Member Electoral Commission, 1877. His law office and home stood on this site. Died, 1895.
streetAddress: NW corner, 5th & Court Sts., Reading
markerCategories: Government & Politics, Government & Politics 19th Century, Professions & Vocations

markerText: Here in 1811, Andrew Henderson and Robert Allison built the second iron furnace in present Blair County. Elias Baker became three-fourths owner in 1836, and in 1844 (as he prepared to build his Greek Revival mansion nearby) he became full owner. The stone store building here was erected about 1837. Until the furnace closed in 1884, it remained in the Baker family, which consistently spelled its name "Alleghany."
streetAddress: PA 36 (Union Ave.) in triangle median, S of 31st St., Altoona
markerCategories: Business & Industry, Furnaces, Iron & Steel, Mansions & Manors

markerText: Founded 1849 as a terminal for westward expansion of the Pennsylvania Railroad. It soon became a major railroad center of the nation. Scene of the War Governors' Conference, 1867.
streetAddress: Logan Blvd., in median where road goes over Mill Run, Altoona
markerCategories: Cities & Towns, Government & Politics, Government & Politics 19th Century, Railroads

markerText: On Sept. 24-26 , 1862, the loyal war governors of the Northern states met at the call of Governor Curtin of Pennsylvania in Altoona. Out of the meeting at the Logan House came new unity, support for Lincoln, and emancipation of the slaves.
streetAddress: US 22 between Hollidaysburg and Duncansville (Missing)
markerCategories: Abraham Lincoln, African American, Government & Politics, Government & Politics 19th Century

markerText: This fine example of Greek Revival Architecture was the home of Elias Baker, a leading ironmaster of the region. Built in 1846, it is now the museum and home of the Blair County Historical Society. Located on the hill opposite this point.
streetAddress: 97 Mansion Blvd., at PA 36 (Union Ave.), Altoona
markerCategories: Buildings & Architecture, Iron & Steel, Mansions & Manors

markerText: Erected 1844-1847. Architect, Robert Cary Long, Jr. Residence of Elias Baker, Ironmaster, and his family, 1848 to 1914. Museum of the Blair County Historical Society since 1922. Entrance to mansion from street in rear.
streetAddress: Baker Blvd. & Mansion Blvd., Altoona
markerCategories: Buildings & Architecture, Iron & Steel, Mansions & Manors

markerText: Formed on February 26, 1846 from Bedford and Huntingdon counties. Named for the Hon. John Blair, a prominent citizen who died in 1832. Hollidaysburg, county seat, was incorporated 1836. City of Altoona, founded 1849, became a major railroad center.
streetAddress: Courthouse, 423 Allegheny St., Hollidaysburg
markerCategories: Government & Politics, Government & Politics 19th Century, Railroads

markerText: Erected 1785 by Thomas Blair. Residence of his son, John Blair, for whom Blair County was named in 1846. John Blair was a member of the General Assembly and until his death, 1832, a leading citizen of the region.
streetAddress: SR 3012 (old US 22) opposite Zimmerman Ln., ~1.4 miles W of Duncansville (MISSING)
markerCategories: Government & Politics, Government & Politics 18th Century, Houses & Homesteads

markerText: Opposite here on the side road is the stone house of Thomas Blair, erected 1785. It was also the home of his son, John Blair, leading citizen of the region for whom Blair County was named in 1846.
streetAddress: opposite 1220 Foot of Ten Rd. (old William Penn Hwy.) near Willow Bridge Ln., W of Duncansville
markerCategories: Government & Politics, Government & Politics 18th Century, Houses & Homesteads

markerText: Here at Hollidaysburg the 127-mile Juniata Division of the Pennsylvania Canal met the Allegheny Portage Railroad, which extended 36 miles west over the mountain to Johnstown. The Juniata Division was opened in 1832, the railroad in March 1834. Regarded as an engineering marvel, the railroad climbed 1398 feet in ten miles.
streetAddress: N Juniata St. (US 22) at Canal Basin Park, W end of Hollidaysburg

markerText: Here was boyhood home of the Black physician who pioneered successful heart surgery, 1893. Founded Provident Hospital, Chicago, 1891. Chief surgeon at Freedmen's Hospital, Washington, D.C., 1894-98. Charter member, College of Surgeons, 1913.
streetAddress: US 22 eastbound (Blair St., 300 block), Hollidaysburg
markerCategories: African American, Professions & Vocations, Science & Medicine

markerText: Built in 1809 by the firm of Canan, Stewart and Moore, and operated until 1877, the furnace produced some of the Juniata iron for which this region was famous. The furnace stack and some of the stone buildings may be seen about one mile to the eastward on the side road.
streetAddress: Int. of Etna Furnace Rd, TR 463 and Wm. Penn Hwy. (Missing)

markerText: The Revolutionary fort site is located a few miles from here. Built 1778 by Daniel Roberdeau to protect lead mines in Sinking Valley which supplied the Continental army.
streetAddress: Skelp Mountain Rd., off I-99 Exit 41, Bellwood

markerText: Site of the Revolutionary fort built by Gen. Daniel Roberdeau in 1778 to protect the Sinking Valley lead mines. The lead was extracted for the production of bullets in support of the patriot cause. This fort was also a supply depot for weapons and ammunition, and it provided settlers a refuge against raids by Tories (loyal to the British) and their Iroquois allies.
streetAddress: at site - Kettle Road (SR 1013), 1 mile SW of Culp (Missing)

markerText: The site, prior to 1748, of a Delaware-Shawnee village called Assunepachla. Here the trader, Frank Stevens, had a fur post as early as 1734. The Kittanning Path led through here.
streetAddress: 444 Old US 22 near Wm. Penn Hwy. intersection, .6 mile E of Hollidaysburg, and SW of Frankstown
markerCategories: Cities & Towns, Native American, Paths & Trails

markerText: World-renowned choral arranger and band leader, Waring was born and raised in Tyrone. In 1919, while attending Penn State, he started "Fred Waring and the Pennsylvanians," a popular musical group that entertained for seven decades on stage, screen, radio, and TV.
streetAddress: SE corner of Pennsylvania Ave. & 11th St., Tyrone

markerText: The spring opposite here was a favorite stopping place of Prince Gallitzin, famous Catholic missionary and founder of the Loretto settlement. He was often known as Father Smith.
streetAddress: Old US 22, 2 miles E of Cambria Co. line

markerText: The spring opposite here was a favorite stopping place of Prince Gallitzin, noted prince-priest and missionary, who founded the settlement at Loretto in 1792. He was also known as Father Smith. Buried at Loretto, site of his chapel.
streetAddress: Old US 22, westbound, 2 miles E of Cambria Co. line

markerText: FDR's Sec. of Interior 1933-46. Builder of public works, ardent conservationist, fierce fighter for human rights, advocate of government as an agent for the public good. This is the site of his boyhood home.
streetAddress: Altoona Area High School, 1415 Sixth Ave., Altoona
markerCategories: Civil Rights, Environment, Government & Politics, Government & Politics 20th Century

markerText: Lancaster native and Altoona businessman and promoter. Built and managed theaters in Pennsylvania and New Jersey. In 1906, he built the opulent Mishler Theater here for stage shows, musical performances, live theater, and vaudeville.
streetAddress: 1208 Twelfth Ave. at Mishler Theater, Altoona

markerText: Along the streams of this region are ruins of many charcoal iron furnaces and forges built between 1790 and 1850 that produced some of the highest quality iron in the nation. The reign of Juniata Iron ended with the rise of coal and coke iron-making. Nearby Springfield Furnace, in operation from 1820-84, produced this type of iron, as did 11 others in Morrison Cove. Royer Mansion, built here in 1815, was ironmaster Samuel Royer's home.
streetAddress: at Royer Mansion, 3909 Piney Creek Rd. (Rt.866), ~5 miles S of Williamsburg
markerCategories: Buildings & Architecture, Coal, Furnaces, Iron & Steel, Mansions & Manors

markerText: Built here in 1902 by E. Joy Morris of Philadelphia, it was among some 250 side-friction figure eight roller coasters in North America. It became the last known ride of this type and the world's oldest known operating roller coaster. A National Historic Landmark.
streetAddress: Lakemont Park 700 Park Ave., Altoona

markerText: At the famous railroad hotel on this site was held the Conference of Northern War Governors, Sept. 24-26, 1862. Governor Andrew Curtin of Pennsylvania called the meeting which united forces behind Lincoln and the Emancipation Proclamation.
streetAddress: 11th Ave. at 13th St., Altoona
markerCategories: Abraham Lincoln, African American, Business & Industry, Government & Politics, Government & Politics 19th Century, Governors, Inns & Taverns

markerText: Oldest stone house in Blair County. Erected by Lazarus Lowry in 1785. Located on the Kittanning Trail, Indian route from Susquehanna to Allegheny rivers.
streetAddress: US 22, 1.1 miles E of Hollidaysburg (Missing)
markerCategories: Buildings & Architecture, Native American, Houses & Homesteads, Paths & Trails

markerText: The PRR built its first repair facilities here in 1850 and opened its first track to Altoona during the same year. By 1925, Altoona was home to the nation's largest concentration of railroad shops, with 16,500 people employed in several locations.
streetAddress: 9th Ave. at 13th St., Altoona

markerText: Here was No. 6 of the ten inclined planes used to carry canal boats by rail. Hollidaysburg to Johnstown. This unique engineering feat was completed in 1834. The road was 36 miles long.
streetAddress: (SR 3012 / old US 22) westbound, just E of Cambria Co. line

markerText: Here was No. 6 of the ten inclined planes used to carry canal boats by rail, Hollidaysburg to Johnstown. This unique engineering feat was completed in 1834. The road was 36 miles long.
streetAddress: (SR 3012 / old US 22) eastbound, just E of Cambria Co. line

markerText: Over 300,000 skilled tradesmen went on strike against US railroads to defend gains by unions during WWI. The Pennsylvania Railroad shops in Altoona led the anti-union opposition. The bitter struggle led to the 1926 Railway Labor Act that upheld unions' right to organize.
streetAddress: 302 E Wopsononock Ave., Altoona, at Blair Bedford Central Labor Council

markerText: A settlement of French Royalists who Fled the French Revolution in 1793 was established in the valley directly opposite this Marker. It was laid out and settled under the direction of Viscount de Noailles and Marquis Antoine Omer Talon. It was hoped that Queen Marie Antoinette might here find safety. Among many distinguished visitors to this place were Louis Phillipe, Duke of Orleans. Later King of France. Prince de Talleyrand, Duke de Montpensier and the Duke de la Rochefoucauld Liancourt.
streetAddress: Mount Rock lookout off US 6, 5 miles N of Wyalusing
markerCategories: Early Settlement, Ethnic & Immigration, Government & Politics 18th Century

markerText: Known also as Tioga Point. Connecticut settlers laid out the village in 1786. Site of ancient Indian village of Teaoga. Base for the Sullivan Campaign into central N.Y. Gateway from Southern N.Y. into Pennsylvania for centuries.
streetAddress: PA 199 (old US 220) at Tioga Point Cemetery, Athens
markerCategories: Cities & Towns, Early Settlement, Military, Native American

markerText: The broad plain which can be seen from this point was the site, 1793-1803, of the French refugee colony. The Great House, built for Marie Antoinette and her son, was there and an entire village founded.
streetAddress: US 6, 4.5 miles N of Wyalusing at Marie Antoinette lookout
markerCategories: Cities & Towns, Early Settlement, Ethnic & Immigration

markerText: Site of the famed French refugee colony is a few miles south. Here exiles laid out a town and built La Grande Maison for the Queen and her son, the heir to the throne of France.
streetAddress: US 6 just E of Lake Rd. (PA 187) at Wysox
markerCategories: Cities & Towns, Early Settlement, Ethnic & Immigration

markerText: Formed on February 21, 1810 from Lycoming and Luzerne counties. Named Ontario County until 1812; renamed for the second U.S. Attorney General, William Bradford. County seat of Towanda was incorporated 1828. Famous for Sullivan's March and David Wilmot.
streetAddress: At County Courthouse, Main St. (US 6) between Court & Park, Towanda
markerCategories: Government & Politics, Government & Politics 19th Century, Military

markerText: Stephen Foster's well-known song, "Camptown Races," was probably inspired by the horse races run from this village to Wyalusing. "The Tioga Waltz," Foster's first music, was completed during his residence in nearby Towanda and Athens in 1840-41.
streetAddress: Junction PA 706 & 409 at Camptown
markerCategories: Cities & Towns, Music & Theater, Sports & Recreation, Writers

markerText: Stephen Foster's title for the well-known song is said to have been taken from nearby Camptown. Foster's residence at Towanda and Athens may have created the association.
streetAddress: Junction US 6 & PA 409, 4.2 miles N of Wyalusing

markerText: Here the Indian voyager down the Chemung lifted his canoe and carried it a hundred and ninety yards across the neck to ascend the Susquehanna.
streetAddress: Pa. 199 at Chemung River Bridge into Athens

markerText: Here was the Western end of the Indian Carrying Path from the Chemung to the Susquehanna Rivers. The Eastern end was 190 Rods Southeast. Fort Sullivan was built across the path.
streetAddress: PA 199 at N end of bridge into Athens (MISSING)

markerText: Leader of Connecticut land claimants. Served in Sullivan Campaign, 1779. Imprisoned in 1787-89 for leading new state movement. Later served in Pa. legislature. Moved here in 1789; died in 1831. Homesite and grave are east of road.
streetAddress: Sheshequin Rd. (SR 1043) just N of Orange Hill Rd. ((SR 1054), ~1 mile SE of Athens at cemetery

markerText: The great Free-Soiler is buried here. Born at Bethany, 1814. Studied law at Wilkes-Barre, 1834. Began practice in Towanda, his home until his death, 1868. His famed Wilmot Proviso introduced August 8, 1846.
streetAddress: William St. at Riverside Cemetery, Towanda (Missing)
markerCategories: African American, Government & Politics, Government & Politics 19th Century

markerText: The great Free-Soiler, who began the fight on slavery extension with the Wilmot Proviso in 1846, lived in this house. Republican Party founder; its first candidate for Governor. He died here in 1868.
streetAddress: U.S. 6 (York Ave.) above Barstow Ave., Towanda
markerCategories: African American, Government & Politics, Government & Politics 19th Century

markerText: Bacteriologist for the US Department of Agriculture who discovered that brucellosis bacteria found in raw milk caused undulant fever in humans. Despite gender discrimination in her field, she published a report in 1918 and promoted milk pasteurization until laws were passed in the late 1920s. She received numerous awards for pioneering contributions in microbiology. Evans graduated from the former Susquehanna Collegiate Institute here.
streetAddress: at entrance to YMCA, College Ave., between 2nd and 3rd Sts., Towanda
markerCategories: Agriculture, Professions & Vocations, Science & Medicine, Women, Writers

markerText: Here, between the Chemung and Susquehanna commanding both rivers, Gen. John Sullivan built a fort Aug. 18, 1779. With a camp on the flats, it was base for the central N.Y. campaign and defeat of the Tory-Indian alliance.
streetAddress: PA 199 & S Main St., south end of Athens
markerCategories: American Revolution, Forts, Military, Native American

markerText: Here within the confines of Fort Sullivan were buried, August 14, 1779, several soldiers killed the previous day in a skirmish at Chemung, as attested by Soloman Talada, soldier in the ranks, who returned to live in Athens the rest of his life. This statement was corroborated by finding skeletons previous to 1839.
streetAddress: 731 Main Street Athens

markerText: Moravian mission founded at Wyalusing Indian town by Zeisberger in 1763. It served as a model for subsequent Indian missions. It was abandoned in 1772, when pastors Ettwein and Roth led some 200 Indians to the mission of Friedensstadt on the Beaver River near Ohio.
streetAddress: US 6 near Moravian Rd., 1.3 miles SE of Wyalusing

markerText: The hill just southeast was the scene, Sept. 29, 1778, of a battle between Col. Thos. Hartley's men from Fort Muncy, and the Indians. Two days before, Hartley had burned Queen Esther's town near present Athens.
streetAddress: U.S. 6, 4.6 miles E of Wyalusing

markerText: On September 29th, 1778 on the hill one mile south east of this marker in the most desperate engagement between Indians and white men in Bradford County, Colonel Thomas Hartley defeated the Indians. He left Fort Muncy September 21st. On the 27th burned Tioga Queen Esther's Town and reached Wyalusing at eleven o'clock on the night of September 28th. This campaign ended Indian incursions in Bradford County and prepared the way for the Sullivan Expedition. Hardby on the east of this marker, led the old Warrior Path and the Sullivan Trail.
streetAddress: off US 6 - Cornell Rd., ~5 miles E of Wyalusing, 1st right past Indian Hill marker traveling east

markerText: Second in command at the Battle of Lime Hill April 14, 1782. He killed the Indian who shot Mrs. Franklin and rescued three of her four stolen children. He was in the engagement at Trenton December 25, 1776 and was presented with a sword by General George Washington for bravery. He broke from the Indians at the Bloody Rock, Wyoming Massace, and swam the Susquehanna River with a bullet in his shoulder and escaped to Wilkes-Barre.
streetAddress: Lime Hill, US 6, W of Wyalusing
markerCategories: American Revolution, George Washington, Military, Native American

markerText: "Father of American Sociology," geologist, and Civil War veteran, L.F. Ward (1841-1913), spent his youth in Myersburg working with his brother, Cyrenus Osborne Ward, labor historian, in their hub factory. He has been called "the American Aristotle."
streetAddress: 24527 Rome Rd. (PA 187), Myersburg
markerCategories: Civil War, Professions & Vocations, Science & Medicine

markerText: Here Apr. 14, 1782, a party led by Sgt. Thos. Baldwin tried to rescue a woman and her children held as Indian captives. In a four-hour battle, three children were saved but the mother was killed.
streetAddress: US 6 at Limehill, 3.7 miles N of Wyalusing

markerText: April 14, 1782, Sergeant Thomas Baldwin's Party in attempting to rescue Mrs. Rosewell Franklin and her four children who had been captured by Indians, met the enemy near this spot after four hours of fighting. Three of the children were rescued but Mrs. Franklin was killed. Sergeant Baldwin's breastworks were located seventy Rods northwest of this marker.
streetAddress: US 6, 3.7 miles N of Wyalusing

markerText: Founded 1681 by William Penn as a Quaker Commonwealth. Birthplace of THE DECLARATION OF INDEPENDENCE and THE CONSTITUTION OF THE UNITED STATES.
streetAddress: Pa. 14, 1.5 miles from state line
markerCategories: Government & Politics, Government & Politics 17th Century, William Penn

markerText: Founded 1681 by William Penn as a Quaker Commonwealth. Birthplace of THE DECLARATION OF INDEPENDENCE and THE CONSTITUTION OF THE UNITED STATES.
streetAddress: US 220 & 309, .3 miles from state line
markerCategories: Government & Politics, Government & Politics 17th Century, William Penn

markerText: The great singing evangelist and gospel song writer lived and taught school at one time in Bradford County. The cemetery monument was built by Sunday School gifts from England and U.S. after his death in 1876.
streetAddress: Pa. 187 in Rome Borough at cemetery, across from church.

markerText: This area was known by pioneers as the "Pine Plains." In 1790 near this spot Timothy Pickering met Red Jacket and his Senecas. They were on the way to the peace council at Tioga Point.
streetAddress: Keystone Ave. (PA 199), at First Church of God, Sayre

markerText: On the terrace below here resided Esther Montour, of the noted French-Indian family, and her group of Munsee Indians. The town was burned in 1778 by Col. Hartley.
streetAddress: US 220 (E side), .3 miles N of Milan (Missing)
markerCategories: Cities & Towns, Early Settlement, Native American, Women

markerText: In 1936 seventy-five percent of Pennsylvania farms had no electric service. During the next five years, with Federal support, 14 consumer-owned cooperatives were formed in the State. Claverack Rural Electric Cooperative, serving parts of eight northeastern Pennsylvania counties, was incorporated October 24, 1936.
streetAddress: US 6 near Goff / W Valley Rd., 3.2 miles E of Wysox

markerText: Indian trail joining the Iroquois country and the Shamokin area, passed near here. Conrad Weiser took this route to Onondaga, capital of the League, to represent the Province in council with the Iroquois.
streetAddress: US 220 near Crest Rd., 3.1 miles NW of Towanda
markerCategories: Government & Politics, Native American, Transportation, Paths & Trails

markerText: A branch of the Warriors Path. Left the Susquehanna at Sheshequin, now Ulster; crossed Sugar Creek; and by valleys of Towanda and Lycoming Creeks reached West Branch, near present Montoursville, where it joined the Shamokin Path.
streetAddress: PA 414, ~.5 mile W of SR 3021, LeRoy Twp, (Missing)

markerText: America's beloved writer of folk tunes and ballads attended, 1840-41, Athens Academy, which stood here. The Tioga Waltz, Foster's first music, was composed at that time.
streetAddress: PA 199 (across from Tioga Point Mus.) in Athens

markerText: The great writer of folk songs and ballads lived in Towanda in 1840-41. He attended Towanda Academy on the hill a short time and stayed with his brother William, a canal official.
streetAddress: U.S. 6 (Main St.) near State St., Towanda

markerTitle: Sullivan Expedition Against the Iroquois Indians, 1779 - Breakneck Hill (PLAQUE)
markerText: BREAKNECK HILL Narrow pass over which Sullivan's Army marched August 9, 1779 is visible across the river in a Southeasterly direction. Six miles of Sullivan's March are in plain view.
streetAddress: Off US 220 between Towanda and Ulster (Missing from site but at Hist. Soc.)
markerCategories: American Revolution, Military, Native American, Paths & Trails

markerTitle: Sullivan Expedition Against the Iroquois Indians, 1779 - Sheshecunnunck (PLAQUE)
markerText: 15 miles from Standing Stone, seventh and last encampment of Sullivan's army on march from Wyoming to Teaoga August 10, 1779, lay on these lowlands by the river.
streetAddress: E side of SR 1043 in Sheshequin Twp., 2.3 miles N of the bridge into Ulster

markerTitle: Sullivan Expedition Against the Iroquois Indians, 1779 - Standing Stone (PLAQUE)
markerText: 9 1/2 miles from Wyalusing, sixth encampement of Sullivan's army on the march from Wyoming to Teaoga August 8-9, 1779, was on river lowlands opposite the Standing Stone.
streetAddress: River Rd. (SR 2016), Standing Stone

markerTitle: Sullivan Expedition Against the Iroquois Indians, 1779 - Teaoga (PLAQUE)
markerText: Teaoga. Indian village 3 miles distant from Sheshecunnunck, site of Sullivan's army encampment August 11-26, 1779, lay one and one-fourth miles south of this point.
streetAddress: Corner of Tioga (PA 199) & Main Sts. (across from Tioga Point Mus.), Athens

markerTitle: Sullivan Expedition Against the Iroquois Indians, 1779 - Wyalusing (PLAQUE)
markerText: 10 1/2 miles from Vanderlip's farm. Fifth encampment of Sullivan's Army on the march from Wyoming to Teaoga, August 6-7, 1779, was on site just west of this road marked by the Moravian Indian town monument.
streetAddress: US 6 at Moravian Rd., 1.4 miles SE of Wyalusing
markerCategories: American Revolution, Military, Native American, Religion

markerText: Gen. John Sullivan's army camped just west Aug. 5-7, 1779, en route to attack the New York Iroquois. A major campaign, destroying 40 villages and ending the Indian-Tory frontier menace.
streetAddress: US 6 near Moravian Rd., just over 1 mile SE of Wyalusing

markerText: Gen. John Sullivan's army camped on the nearby river lowlands Aug. 8-9, 1779 en route to attack the Six Nations Iroquois. Sixth camp between Wyoming and Fort Sullivan.
streetAddress: US 6 at Tamarack Rd., ~6.2 miles NW of Wyalusing, at Standing Stone Twp. Bldg.

markerText: Gen. John Sullivan's army camped on the Sheshequin Flats below, Aug. 9-10, 1779. The seventh and last overnight stop on the way to Tioga Point.
streetAddress: U.S. 220, 1.3 miles N of Ulster

markerText: This strategic locality between the Chemung and the Susquehanna, shows signs of age-old residence by various Indian groups. Graves of an Andaste chief and his followers were unearthed here in 1883-95.
streetAddress: PA 199, S end Chemung River Bridge into Athens (just past bar & grill)

markerText: Teaoga. A watch town, the south door of the Iroquois House was situated at the meeting of the rivers 200 rods to the northeast. Queen Esther's Town of the Delaware Indians was 100 rods to the east along the Chemung River banks. Both towns were destroyed by Colonel Thomas Hartley and his troops Sept. 27, 1778. These flats for 5 miles known as Queen Esther's Flats were grazing ground for their herds.
streetAddress: US 220 (E side), 1 mile N of Milan
markerCategories: Cities & Towns, Early Settlement, Native American

markerText: A great Indian highway from Six Nations country, New York, to the Catawba country in the Carolinas. It made its way through the Allegheny Mountains by following the Susquehanna and Juniata valleys.
streetAddress: GAR Hwy. (US 6), 1.3 miles N of Wyalusing

markerText: Named for an early town of the Munsee Delawares, which occupied the flats south of the present town. In 1760 Munsees under Papoonhank welcomed Post here, on his way toward a great Indian council beyond Allegheny River.
streetAddress: GAR Hwy. (US 6) & Bridge St. at SE end of Wyalusing
markerCategories: Cities & Towns, Early Settlement, Native American

markerText: Named for an early town of the Munsee Delawares, which occupied the flats south of the present town. In 1760 Munsees under Papoonhank welcomed Post here, on his way toward a great Indian council beyond Allegheny River.
streetAddress: GAR Hwy. (US 6) at NW end of Wyalusing
markerCategories: Cities & Towns, Government & Politics 18th Century, Native American

markerText: Lookout on Warriors Path, entering Pennsylvania from the headwaters of Delaware, Susquehanna, and Chemung Rivers. Over it traveled Six Nations war parties against southern Indians, and peace missions to Philadelphia.
streetAddress: US 6 & US 309, 1.3 miles N of Wyalusing at lookout (Missing)

markerText: Preeminent 20th century photographer. Siskind's influential images of Bucks County architecture from 1939 to 1945 brought about a change from documentary style to a radical abstract style, setting a new standard in American art photography.
streetAddress: 26 E. Swamp Rd. (Pa. 313) east of Pa. 611, Doylestown (Cross Keys)

markerText: On Feb. 21, 1861, the train carrying the President-elect from Springfield, Ill., to his Inauguration in Washington, D.C., stopped briefly near this point. Mr. Lincoln appeared on the rear platform and spoke to the assembled crowd, estimated at more than a thousand people.
streetAddress: Pond St., between Grundy Tower Dr. and Beaver St., Bristol, back from road near fence
markerCategories: Abraham Lincoln, Government & Politics, Government & Politics 19th Century

markerText: Country estate of Nicholas Biddle (1786-1844), poet, lawyer, agriculturalist, state senator, and president of the Second Bank of the United States. Biddle's struggle with President Andrew Jackson over the Bank's financial control of the nation's monetary system was one of the most controversial issues of the era. Andalusia, designed by Benjamin H. Latrobe and Thomas U. Walter, shows the influence of both Regency and Greek Revival styles of architecture. Named a National Historic Landmark in 1966.
streetAddress: 1237 State Road, Andalusia (Bensalem Township)
markerCategories: Agriculture, Buildings & Architecture, Business & Industry, Government & Politics, Government & Politics 19th Century, Professions & Vocations, Writers

markerText: First licensed in 1763, it was headquarters of the Committee of Observation and Inspection, which organized the revolutionary movement in Bucks County in 1775 & 1776. It was also the site where the county's first military organizations of the Revolution mustered in 1775, & served as General Nathanael Greene's Headquarters in 1776.
streetAddress: York Rd. (Rt. 263) & Durham Rd. (Rt. 413), Buckingham
markerCategories: American Revolution, Government & Politics, Inns & Taverns, Military

markerText: Early river port laid out as Buckingham, 1697. The third oldest borough in Pennsylvania, chartered Nov. 14, 1720. County seat of Bucks, 1705-26. Travel and trade center for over two hundred years.
streetAddress: US 13, .8 miles N of 4th Ave., at Turnpike off-ramp, N of Bristol (Missing)
