It was the path prior to 1670 for their conquest of the Lenni-Lenape or Delaware Indians and for trade with the first Dutch and Swedish settlers on the Delaware River. Thousands of Beaver skins yearly being carried down over this "Beversrede" or Beaver Road to Fort Beversrede. On the site of Philadelphia and to other neighboring trading posts.
streetAddress: Bus. US 322 at Church Ave., SE of West Chester
markerCategories: Early Settlement, Ethnic & Immigration, Native American, Paths & Trails

markerText: Colonial grist mill built in 1710 by Thomas Jerman. One of the earliest mills in present Chester County; thought to be the oldest one in this country in continuous operation.
streetAddress: US 202, 1.5 miles NE of Paoli (Missing)

markerText: A borough from 1853 to 1914, Hopewell was a laboratory for progressive farming, milling, and educational practices. Samuel Dickey (1769-1835) was an agricultural innovator, and the Dickeys pioneered in establishing area schools. The family, spurred by available water power, developed this valley between 1815 and the 1870s. Much of its 19th-century character endures in the land and its buildings.
streetAddress: Intersection of Hopewell & Lower Hopewell Roads, Lower Oxford & E. Nottingham Twps.

markerText: Forge built 1744 by Wm. Bird; furnace built 1770 by his son Mark. Furnace and other remains of an iron making community of the era, administered by the National Park Service, are about 3 miles away.
streetAddress: PA 345 at Warwick, just N of junction PA 23

markerText: Born in West Chester in 1888, Pippin occupied this house from 1920 until his death in 1946. A self-taught black artist, he painted while living here such notable works as "Domino Players," "John Brown Going to His Hanging," and the "Holy Mountain" series.
streetAddress: 327 Gay St., West Chester

markerText: Founded by free Blacks who had settled in this area, it was first known as the "African Meeting House." Formally organized in 1843 as an African Union Methodist Protestant church. A station stop on the Underground Railroad, its many visitors included Frederick Douglass and Sojourner Truth.
streetAddress: Old US 1 (Baltimore Pike) near Ashmun Rd., N of Lincoln University campus, Lower Oxford Twp.
markerCategories: African American, Religion, Underground Railroad, Houses & Homesteads

markerText: One of the first nurserymen in the nation and the author of the first book on North American trees and shrubs, Arbustum Americanum: The American Grove, Marshall is known as the Father of American Dendrology. He regularly supplied native American plants to prominent Europeans eager to learn about species new to them. His plants graced the gardens of England's King George III and King Louis XVI of France. He built and lived in this house.
streetAddress: 1407 W Strasburg Rd., West Chester
markerCategories: Agriculture, Environment, Professions & Vocations, Science & Medicine, Writers

markerText: African American self-taught artist who depicted life in rural Chester County in the first half of the 20th century. The daughter of a former slave, Jones completed more than 300 works in her 70s and 80s. She worked in watercolor, oil, and pencil in a style typical of folk art. Her works illustrated personal observations of family and farm life, nature, landscapes, early technologies, human interaction, and slavery. Jones resided on a nearby farm.
streetAddress: PA 82 (Doe Run Rd.) at Rokeby Rd., East Fallowfield Twp.

markerText: The last of the Indians in Chester County was born in the vale about 300 yards to the east on the land of the protector of her people the Quaker assemblyman WILLIAM WEBB. Her mother was Indian Sarah and her grandmother Indian Jane of the Unami group * their totem * the Tortoise * Of the Lenni-Lenape or Delaware Indians
streetAddress: PA 52 (E side), .2 mile N of US 1 junction, Kennett Square
markerCategories: Government & Politics 18th Century, Native American, Religion, Women

markerText: Quaker abolitionists, the Mendenhalls harbored freedom seekers on the Underground Railroad in their nearby home, Oakdale. Originally members of Old Kennett Meeting, which became divided on the issue of slavery, they helped found Longwood Progressive Meeting in 1853. Dinah was a member of a committee that met with Pres. Lincoln in 1862 to urge him to enact the Emancipation Proclamation. Both were firm supporters of women's voting rights.
streetAddress: 301 Kennett Pike (PA 52), at Hillendale Rd., Kennett Twp.
markerCategories: Abraham Lincoln, African American, Religion, Underground Railroad, Women

markerText: The noted agriculturalist purchased land just north of here in 1792 and named it "Como Farm." Here, he conducted numerous experiments on crop rotation and maintenance of soil fertility. Bordley planned new devices for seeding and reaping wheat. His works on Rotation of Crops and Husbandry and Rural Affairs were widely read. Died, 1804.
streetAddress: Strasburg Rd. (SR 3062) & Broad Rd., W of Marshalltown

markerText: His absolute integrity, mechanical ability, inventive genius, and practical resourcefulness brought about improved processes and products in the iron and steel industry in America. He introduced the three-high rolls into the Cambria mill, applied the Bessemer process to American practice, improved the manufacture of armor plate. Fritz was born 1.3 miles NE of here in 1822.
streetAddress: PA 41 at Derry Mtg. Rd. (PA 796), 2.8 miles SE of Cochranville (Missing)
markerCategories: Business & Industry, Invention, Iron & Steel, Professions & Vocations

markerText: Born in this vicinity on Sept. 22, 1827, the noted Army Engineer is remembered chiefly for having set the exact boundary between the Oregon Territory and Canada. His survey, begun in 1857, was halted by service in the Civil War and was not completed until 1869. He later became Supt. of West Point.
streetAddress: Business US 30 at Veterans Hospital, near N Cain Rd., E of Coatesville
markerCategories: Civil War, Environment, Government & Politics, Military, Professions & Vocations

markerText: Conservationist, father of the State Forest idea in Pennsylvania, lived in this house from 1876 until his death in 1922. He pioneered in the development of forest fire control, reforestation, and scientific forestry.
streetAddress: NW corner, N Church St. & W Lafayette St., West Chester

markerText: Built c.1747 by Samuel Lightfoot, this mill provided feed and grain to the local community and exemplifies a turning point in American industrial technology. A rare surviving example of a colonial-era custom water-powered grist mill, its horizontal counter-shaft power system remains intact. The mill remained active until the 1930s. It is maintained by a preservation trust and is a National Historic Landmark.
streetAddress: 1730 Conestoga Rd. (Rt. 401) near Rt. 113, Chester Spgs. (NE of Downingtown)

markerText: The first published biography of Abraham Lincoln was printed in this building on Feb.11, 1860. It was prepared from Lincoln's own notes and served to introduce him to the public as a potential presidential candidate.
streetAddress: 28 W. Market St., West Chester
markerCategories: Abraham Lincoln, Government & Politics, Government & Politics 19th Century, Publishing & Journalism

markerText: Chartered as Ashmun Institute, April 29, 1854. Founded by Rev. John Miller Dickey for the purpose of providing liberal higher education for people of African ancestry in America. In 1866, it became Lincoln University, interracial and international.
streetAddress: Baltimore Pike (SR 3026) across from university, NE of Oxford

markerText: An African American steelworker, Walker was burned to death by a mob near here on August 13, 1911. He was accused of killing Edgar Rice, a white security guard and former borough policeman. Fifteen local men and teenage boys were indicted for their involvement in Walker's death but were acquitted of all charges. Nation-wide outrage led to the NAACP's national anti-lynching campaign and inspired Pennsylvania's 1923 anti-lynching law.
streetAddress: Doe Run Rd. (Rt. 82S), approx. 1/4 mile from Coatesville city limits (at Phila. Power Plant access g
markerCategories: African American, Civil Rights, Government & Politics 20th Century

markerText: The Manor of Steyning of 15,500 acres patented by William Penn for "fatherly love" and one beaver skin yearly to his daughter Laetitia Penn at Philadelphia, October 23, 1701 is here marked on its western line adjoining a tract of 14,500 acres which the proprietor patented to his son WILLIAM PENN, JUNIOR May 24, 1706
streetAddress: W Baltimore Pike (SR 3046) southbound, .5 mile W of Kennett Square
markerCategories: Government & Politics, Mansions & Manors, Native American, William Penn

markerText: Minguannan Indian Town was located here. The chief Machaloha or Owhala and his people of the Unami group *Their totem*The tortoise*of the Lenni-Lenape or Delawares sold to William Penn the lands between Delaware River and Chesapeake Bay to the falls of Susquehanna River October 18, 1683.
streetAddress: Junction of London Tract Rd. (SR 3034), Sharpless Rd., and S Bank Rd., 1.5 miles NE of Strickersvill
markerCategories: Cities & Towns, Early Settlement, Government & Politics 17th Century, Native American, William Penn

markerText: The chiefs Pokhais, Sepopawny and Muttagooppa with their people, of the Unami group *Their totem * The tortoise * of the Lenni-Lenape or Delawares were moved from Lower Ridley and Crum Creeks by William Penn to a square tract of 500 acres on the north side of this road East of Ridley Creek, the only Indian Reservation the Proprietor ever established 1701.
streetAddress: West Chester Pike (PA 3), .5 mile E of Street Rd. (PA 926) & equidistant between West Chester and Ne
markerCategories: Cities & Towns, Early Settlement, Native American, William Penn

markerText: From this ridge General Howe directed the movements of the British Army at the Battle of Brandywine, September 11, 1777.
streetAddress: Birmingham Rd. (SR 2001) & Country Club Rd. at driveway to Osborne Hill, S of West Chester

markerText: Emboldened by the 1850 Fugitive Slave Law, Maryland slave catchers kidnapped Rachel and Elizabeth Parker from the Nottingham area in 1851. Rachel's employer Joseph Miller was murdered in a failed attempt to rescue her from Baltimore. Public outrage led Pa. officials to seek the sisters' release in a Md. civil court case that secured their freedom in 1853. The forcible enslavement of two young free black women galvanized antislavery sentiment.
streetAddress: At Fremont Cemetery & Union Methodist Church, 321 Fremont Rd., Nottingham, PA
markerCategories: African American, Government & Politics 19th Century, Women

markerText: Between 1908 and 1987, more than 10,500 Pennsylvanians with developmental disabilities lived here. Public controversy over the inhumane treatment of residents and two decades of complex litigation, including three arguments before the US Supreme Court, led to the institution's closure. Groundbreaking advocacy and new public policy, including transition to community-based living, made Pennhurst a milestone in the disabilities civil rights movement.
streetAddress: Schuylkill Rd. (PA 724) near Bridge St., Spring City
markerCategories: Civil Rights, Education, Government & Politics 20th Century

markerText: Founded 1681 by William Penn as a Quaker Commonwealth. Birthplace of THE DECLARATION OF INDEPENDENCE and THE CONSTITUTION OF THE UNITED STATES.
streetAddress: US 1, just N of state line
markerCategories: Government & Politics, Government & Politics 17th Century, William Penn

markerText: Founded 1681 by William Penn as a Quaker Commonwealth. Birthplace of THE DECLARATION OF INDEPENDENCE and THE CONSTITUTION OF THE UNITED STATES.
streetAddress: PA 41 at Kaolin Rd. overpass, approx. .7 miles from state line, New Garden Twp.
markerCategories: Government & Politics, Government & Politics 17th Century, William Penn

markerText: Famed Indian trader and interpreter bought a tract of 500 acres in this area in 1736. This site is a part of the tract. He died in 1742. Bezellon and his wife, Martha, lie buried in St. John's churchyard at Compass, Penna.
streetAddress: West Chester Rd (SR 3064) at Oak St., S end of Coatesville
markerCategories: Early Settlement, Native American, Professions & Vocations

markerText: This was the nation's first major toll road, built by a private company incorporated 1792 by the state legislature. Completed two years later and praised as the finest highway of its day, the stone-and-gravel turnpike stretched 62 miles. The 35th milestone out of Philadelphia was placed here. Early in the 20th century, this road was acquired by the state; it became part of the transcontinental Lincoln Highway and U.S. 30.
streetAddress: E Lincoln Hwy. (Bus. Rt. 30), near Veterans Dr., Cain Twp., just E of Coatesville

markerText: Established in 1783 and incorporated in 1855, the Phoenix "works" produced nails, rail, Civil War cannons, weaponry for 20th century wars, and structural steel. Among its well known products were the Griffen Gun, 1861, and the Phoenix Column, 1862. Closed in 1987.
streetAddress: Main St. at Price St. near municipal parking lot, Phoenixville
markerCategories: Business & Industry, Civil War, Iron & Steel, Military

markerText: ...was located on the other side of Brandywine Creek from here in the Great Bend Rattlesnake Trail led thence over Point Lookout to the rocks on Cristina Creek in present Wilmington. The Chief Secetareus and his people of the Unami group - their totem-the tortoise - of the Lenni-Lenape or Delawares sold to William Penn the land between Chester Creek and Christina Creek December 19, 1683
streetAddress: Creek Rd. (PA 100? / DE 100), ~.1 mile N of DE state line, and at Delaware County line (MISSING)
markerCategories: Cities & Towns, Early Settlement, Native American, William Penn

markerText: Boyhood home of this composer of orchestral and vocal works, including the "Adagio for Strings" and "Knoxville: Summer of 1915." Won Pulitzer Prizes in music, 1958 & 1963. Graduate, Curtis Institute. He wrote West Chester High's Alma Mater song.
streetAddress: 107 S Church St., West Chester

markerText: Cornwallis' Division of the British Army halted here September 11, 1777, on its march to the battlefield of Brandywine.
streetAddress: At Birmingham Rd. (SR 3061) & Squires Dr., S of PA 842 SW of West Chester

markerText: The largest reserved estate of the Penns in Chester County. It was first authorized by William Penn as a 10,000 acre tract in 1701. After resurvey in 1730, it contained 8,313 acres, including most of present Wallace Township. The southern boundary line of the Manor was near this point.
streetAddress: Springton Rd (SR 4021) & Highspire Rd., 1 mile N of US 322, NW of Downingtown, Wallace Twp.
markerCategories: Government & Politics, Government & Politics 18th Century, Mansions & Manors, William Penn

markerTitle: Star of the West, Tent No. Six
markerText: An African American women's community service organization, chartered 1865. A part of the United Order of Tents, J. R. Giddings and Jollifee Union, founded in 1847 and named for abolitionist Congressman Giddings and his law partner.
streetAddress: 113 S Adams St., West Chester

markerText: One of the premier music venues outside of Nashville, the park featured many of the biggest stars of country and bluegrass. Operated by the Waltman family from 1940 to 1995, it supported the transition from pre-WWII "hillbilly music" to the nationally popular country music genre. Featured artists included Hank Williams, Loretta Lynn, Dolly Parton, Randy Travis, and Bill Monroe. Live unreleased recordings of major performers have been preserved.
streetAddress: S Jennersville Rd. (PA 796)at Waltman Ln., West Grove

markerText: The painter and poet was born Mar. 12, 1822, a mile away. Author of well-known "Sheridan's Ride." Spent mature years in Europe, but died in New York City, May 11, 1872, and is buried in Philadelphia.
streetAddress: Horseshoe Pike (US 322) at Corner Ketch Rd.(SR 4037), NW of Downingtown

markerText: The signer of the Declaration of Independence, Chief Justice of Pennsylvania and Governor, from 1799 to 1808, was born on this farm on March 19, 1734. Also active in the politics of Delaware, he encouraged Caesar Rodney to cast the deciding vote for American independence.
streetAddress: 1895 New London Rd. (PA 896) between Pennbrook Dr. and Walnut Glen Rd., NW of PA 841, Franklin Twp.
markerCategories: Government & Politics, Government & Politics 18th Century, Governors

markerText: September 11, 1777, while on the march to the Battlefield of Brandywine, the British Army under Howe and Cornwallis crossed the Brandywine at the ford just south of this point.
streetAddress: Camp Linden Rd. (SR 3023), .2 mile E of Northbrook Rd. (SR 3058), Marshallton (W Bradford Twp.)

markerText: Opened in 1943, it was among the nation's largest military hospitals by the end of World War II. Able to treat more than 3,000 patients in over 100 buildings, the facility specialized in the pioneering treatment of war-related eye and burn injuries, introducing innovations in eye surgery, plastic surgery, and rehabilitation. The hospital treated casualties of World War II, the Korean War, and the Vietnam Conflict before closing in 1974.
streetAddress: near 1401 Charlestown Rd., Phoenixville
markerCategories: Military, Military Post-Civil War, Science & Medicine

markerText: Village settled by the workers at iron forge begun in 1742. The forge and part of village were burned by the British army in 1777. Washington's quarters during the winter of 1777-78 were in Isaac Potts' house, a part of the original village.
streetAddress: 1801 Valley Forge Rd. (PA23), across from Orchard Ln., Schuylkill Twp.
markerCategories: Early Settlement, George Washington, Government & Politics, Government & Politics 18th Century, Iron & Steel

markerText: Village settled by the workers at iron forge begun in 1742. The forge and part of village were burned by the British army in 1777. Washington's quarters during the winter of 1777-78 were in the Isaac Potts' house, a part of the original village.
streetAddress: Valley Forge Rd. (PA 23) across from Valley Forge Post Office, Schuylkill Twp.
markerCategories: American Revolution, Business & Industry, Cities & Towns, George Washington, Iron & Steel, Military

markerText: Built 1737 by Anna Nutt and Co. Made first Franklin stoves, 1742. Supplied shot and cannon for American revolutionists. Furnace a mile and a half away on side road; iron mines a mile west on the highway.
streetAddress: Ridge Rd. (PA 23) at Warwick Furnace Rd., between Warwick & Knauertown

markerText: An internationally significant artist who worked primarily in wood, Esherick was a leader of the Studio Craft Movement. He is best known for his organic sculptural furniture and his ability to transform utilitarian objects into art. From 1926 until his death, he lived and worked nearby in his handcrafted studio, which he called his autobiography. His work continues to inspire contemporary artists and designers today.
streetAddress: Horseshoe Trial & Country Club Rd., Phoenixville

markerText: Founded Clement Atkinson Memorial Hospital here, 1936, offering quality health care to all despite inability to pay. First African American president of Chester County Medical Society; Pa. Practitioner of the year, 1960. A 1924 graduate of Howard University, he began his Coatesville practice in 1927.
streetAddress: 824 E Chestnut St., Coatesville

markerText: Physician, Congressman, began a service of 33 years as president of Bank of Chester County in this building, 1830. Especially noted for his many contributions to the science and study of botany in the early 1800's. He died in 1863.
streetAddress: 13 N. High St. between Market & Gay Sts., West Chester
markerCategories: Environment, Government & Politics 19th Century, Professions & Vocations, Science & Medicine

markerText: The first Woman's Rights Convention in Pennsylvania was held here, June 2-3, 1852, four years after the famous Seneca Falls, New York, Convention. It adopted resolutions promoting the legal, educational, and vocational rights of women.
streetAddress: 225 N. High St., at Co. Historical Soc., West Chester
markerCategories: Civil Rights, Education, Professions & Vocations, Women

markerText: Named for Capt. Samuel Brady (1756-1795), famed frontier scout and the subject of many legends. Near here in June 1779 -- in what was then Seneca territory -- he led a force seeking to redress the killing of a settler and her four children, and the taking of two children as prisoners. The force surrounded a party of seven Indians -- apparently both Seneca and Munsee -- killing their leader (a Munsee warrior) and freeing the two children.
streetAddress: PA 68 / T581, 1.3 miles E of Brady's Bend at Lookout

markerText: A short distance NW of here is the well-preserved cold blast furnace, named for James Buchanan. It was built in 1844; abandoned, 1858, due to lack of timber. At the time of its operation, the iron industry was very prosperous in Clarion County.
streetAddress: PA 58 just N of PA 368, just E of Callensburg
markerCategories: Business & Industry, Coal, Furnaces, Iron & Steel

markerText: Formed March 11, 1839 out of Armstrong and Venango counties. Named for the Clarion River. Early center of iron industry. Noted also for its coal resources and lumbering. The county seat, Clarion, was incorporated as a borough on April 6, 1841.
streetAddress: In front of Courthouse, Main St. between N 5th Ave. & N Jefferson Pl., Clarion
markerCategories: Business & Industry, Coal, Government & Politics, Government & Politics 19th Century, Iron & Steel

markerText: Near here, at the mouth of Town Run on Redbank Creek, a Shawnee village stood in the late 18th century. Called "Fishbasket" for these waters' immense schools of fish, it was at the junction of at least two major paths traveled by Native Americans: the Frankstown-Venango and Punxsutawney-Venango Paths. Prehistoric fortified Indian villages, revealed by archaeological investigations, also existed in this locale.
streetAddress: Brookvile St. (Rt. 28), at Park Rd., across from Redbank Valley Park entrance, Redbank Twp.
markerCategories: Cities & Towns, Early Settlement, Native American, Paths & Trails

markerText: Oldest golf course in continuous use in the U.S. In 1887, land was made available to the newly formed Foxburg Golf Club by Joseph M. Fox, its first president. Course was enlarged from five to nine holes in 1888. The Foxburg Country Club purchased, in 1924, the original land which it had been leasing.
streetAddress: St. Petersburg Rd. (PA 58) near Summit Ave., N end of Foxburg

markerText: Just west of this point can be seen the well-preserved interior of cold blast furnace built in 1845. It was one of numerous iron furnaces operated in Clarion County from about 1829-1867. The County, then, was often referred to as "The Iron County."
streetAddress: Miola Rd. (SR 1005 / old PA 966) at White Oak Dr. (SR 1004), between Clarion and Scotch Hill
markerCategories: Business & Industry, Coal, Furnaces, Iron & Steel

markerText: In 1936 seventy-five percent of Pennsylvania farms had no electric service. During the next five years, with Federal support, 14 consumer-owned cooperatives were formed in this State. Serving users in seven counties of western Pennsylvania, Central Electric Cooperative at Parker was incorporated July 12, 1937.
streetAddress: at co-op, PA 368 near Terwilliger Rd., 1 mile E of Parker

markerText: Indians traveling from the Allegheny to the West Branch by way of Portage-Driftwood Creeks, carried their canoes over the divide -- a distance of 23 miles -- to the other "Canoe Place," near present Emporium Junction.
streetAddress: US 219 just W of Stifflertown/Buterbaugh Rd., .5 miles N of Stifflertown (Missing)

markerText: While working for the Clearfield Cheese Co. on nearby Meadow St., he invented the first commercially successful process for individually wrapped cheese slices. A patent was issued in 1956. An engineer, Nawrocki secured eleven food processing patents over his career.
streetAddress: 424 State St., (Rt. 879), Curwensville

markerText: Former camping place at the junction of two Indian paths: the Great Shamokin, running from Sunbury to Kittanning; and the path to Venango, now Franklin. During War of 1812, Maj. McClelland's force camped here. Spring is 60 yards SW.
streetAddress: Pa. 410, .5 mile SW of Luthersburg
markerCategories: Military, Native American, Sports & Recreation, Paths & Trails

markerText: Name of the Indian village located here, and visited by C.F. Post while traveling to an Indian council at Kuskuski in 1758. The later Clearfield is said to get its name from clearings made by grazing bison along nearby creeks.
streetAddress: PA 879 & S 2nd St., S end of Clearfield
markerCategories: Early Settlement, Government & Politics 18th Century, Native American

markerText: Formed March 26, 1804 out of Huntingdon and Lycoming counties. Clear fields, found by early travelers, gave rise to the name. County was important for logging and rafting on the West Branch, 1850-1901. The county seat, Clearfield, was incorporated 1840.
streetAddress: County Historical Museum, E. Pine St. & Front St., Clearfield
markerCategories: Government & Politics, Government & Politics 19th Century, Transportation

markerText: Noted band composer (1881-1955) lived most of his life in Penfield and was church organist here. Rosenkrans wrote piano and organ music and hymns, as well as over 200 band numbers. Among his marches are "Triumphant Battalions" and "Our Glorious Flag."
streetAddress: Pa. 255 at Methodist Church, Penfield

markerText: Near here stood the iron furnace erected 1817 by Peter Karthaus. Rebuilt 1836 by Peter Ritner and John Say, it became in 1839 one of the earliest to use coke in place of charcoal. Abandoned at the end of the same year.
streetAddress: Market St. (PA 879) near Park Ave., Karthaus
markerCategories: Business & Industry, Coal, Furnaces, Iron & Steel

markerText: The first road to the northwest frontier of Pennsylvania. Opened to the Allegheny River in 1804. In this section, it followed, generally, the course of the Chinklacamoose Path. During the War of 1812, troops under Major McClellan were transported over it to Erie. Highway crosses the route of old road at this point.
streetAddress: Behringer Hwy. (US 322) at Thunderbird Rd., SW of Dubois

markerText: The great singing evangelist and gospel song writer was born July 9, 1838, in a log house which stood a little distance from here. He lived and worked on the farm and in nearby lumber camps until the age of 16.
streetAddress: Bennetts Valley Hwy. (PA 255), 2.2 miles NE of Penfield
markerCategories: Agriculture, Business & Industry, Music & Theater, Performers, Religion, Writers

markerText: One of the most significant evangelical Christian authors of the 20th century, Tozer was born a few miles south of here in LaJose (Newburg). A pastor with The Christian and Missionary Alliance and a nationally recognized theologian, lecturer and writer, he was the featured speaker here at the Mahaffey Camp Summer Bible Conference in the 1940s and 1950s. Over 3 million copies of his more than 40 books are in print throughout the world.
streetAddress: 1598 Mahaffey Grampian Hwy. (Rt. 219), Mahaffey, near camp entrance

markerText: State Senator, 1841-1847; Governor of Pennsylvania, 1852-1855; and U.S. Senator, 1856-1861. Opposed slavery; favored a Southern compromise to avoid the Civil War. His brother, John, was elected Governor of California, 1852. Resided here.
streetAddress: 11 North Second St., Clearfield
markerCategories: Civil War, Government & Politics, Government & Politics 19th Century, Governors

markerText: Clearfield native and fur trader, Leonard was second in command of the Joseph Reddeford Walker Expedition from 1831-1834 to find a route to the Pacific Ocean through the Sierra Nevada Mountains. Leonard served as the expedition''s clerk and chronicler, recording the first non-native American encounter of giant sequoia trees. In 1839 Leonard published his account of the expedition, recognized for its detailed descriptions.
streetAddress: Corner of Daisy St. Ext. (Rt. 322) and Leonard St., Clearfield

markerText: Formed on June 21, 1839 out of Lycoming and Centre counties. Named probably for New York's Gov. DeWitt Clinton. Site of "Tiadaghton Declaration of Independence," 1776. In 19th century a lumbering center. Lock Haven, the county seat, became a city in 1870.
streetAddress: Clinton Co. Courthouse, N Jay & E Water (PA 120) Sts., Lock Haven
markerCategories: Business & Industry, Government & Politics, Government & Politics 19th Century

markerText: Governor of Pennsylvania, 1895-1899; born, 1849, on a farm 4.5 miles SE of here. During his term, the State Department of Agriculture was created and the present State Capitol planned. Lived most of his life in Bellefonte. Died there in 1903.
streetAddress: Nittany Valley Dr. (PA 64), N of Long Run Rd. (PA 477) NW of Salona
markerCategories: Agriculture, Government & Politics, Government & Politics 19th Century, Governors

markerText: A defensive log house outpost, stockaded in 1777. Located on high ground on the south bank, opposite this spot, it commanded the Susquehanna. Abandoned in the Great Runaway of 1778.
streetAddress: PA 150, just NE of McElhatten Dr., Lock Haven (Missing)

markerText: William Reed's stockaded house was the westernmost defense for Susquehanna Valley settlers. The site of the pioneer outpost is a few blocks ahead at the monument near the bridge.
streetAddress: W Main St. at intersection with 6th St. and W Water St. (PA 120), Lock Haven

markerText: Many Indian nations have occupied the Great Island in the river just south of here. Trails led from the Genesee, Ohio, Potomac, and Susquehanna North Branch. Delawares and Shawnees stopped here for a time on their migration west.
streetAddress: Woodward Ave. (PA 150/old US 220), just E of Pine Ridge Dr., ~1.3 miles NE of Lock Haven

markerText: By the Indian path along Bald Eagle Creek, in 1772, Bishop Ettwein, Moravian, brought some 200 Christian Mohicans and Delawares from Friedenshuetten, near Wyalusing, to Friedensstadt on the Beaver.
streetAddress: Eagle Valley Rd. (PA 150/old US 220) near Beech Creek Ave., Mill Hall Boro

markerText: Against expert advice, Dorcie Calhoun drilled Leidy Township's first successful deep gas well about a quarter-mile south of here. On January 8, 1950, the well hit natural gas at a depth of 5,659 feet, and for a time it brought up an estimated 15 million cubic feet per day. This news attracted national attention, and within months more than 30 companies and independents were drilling here before production ceased.
streetAddress: Kettle Creek Rd. (SR 4001) just W of the Leidy Bridge over Kettle Creek (Spice Wood Run Rd.), Leidy

markerText: Division was built from Northumberland to Lock Haven in 1828-34. Until 1889 boats carried iron, lumber and manufacturers from this area to eastern markets. Here the Bald Eagle Cross Cut Canal joined the division connecting with it by two locks, a dam and a tow-path bridge.
streetAddress: E Main St. (PA 150), between Jay & Locust Alley, Lock Haven

markerText: Much-traveled Indian path; followed north shore of Susquehanna from Shamokin, now Sunbury, to the Big Island at Lock Haven. Used by Delawares and Shawnees on migration to the Ohio country before French and Indian War.
streetAddress: PA 150, ~6 miles NE of Lock Haven (Missing)

markerText: An ancient Indian trail connected the West Branch of the Susquehanna with the Upper Allegheny. From the Great Island at Lock Haven it followed the West Branch, the Sinnemahoning, and Portage Creek, to the Seneca Country.
streetAddress: PA 120, ~14 miles NW of Lock Haven

markerText: Under this elm, on July 4, 1776, resolves declaring independence were drawn prior to news of action by Congress at Philadelphia. This was an expression of the spirit common to the frontier and led by the famous Fair Play men.
streetAddress: River Rd. (SR 1016 / old US 220), at Bonner Ln., SE of Avis

markerText: Here July 4, 1776, pioneer settlers of the West Branch resolved independence from Britain. This historic tree still stands about two miles from here at the junction of the Susquehanna and Pine Creek.
streetAddress: PA 220 northbound, just SW of exit 120 (PA44 N, Pine Creek), NE of Avis

markerText: The nearby Friends meetinghouse, built about 1775, was the place of worship for early Quaker settlers among the pioneers of this region. Catawissa itself was laid out by William Hughs, a Berks County Quaker.
streetAddress: South St. between 3rd & 4th Sts., Catawissa

markerText: At Catawissa, three miles distant, is the Friends meetinghouse built about 1775. The log structure is still standing and is a fine example of a pioneer place of worship.
streetAddress: On ramp to PA 42 - Catawissa from US 11N, .7 mile SW of Bloomsburg

markerText: Formed March 22, 1813 out of Northumberland County. Named in honor of America. County seat, Bloomsburg, became this State's only incorporated town in 1870. A Friends meetinghouse was built at Catawissa about 1789. "Twin covered bridges" at Forks are a unique site.
streetAddress: County Courthouse, Main St. between Centre St. and Whiteman Ave., Bloomsburg
markerCategories: Cities & Towns, Government & Politics, Government & Politics 19th Century, Religion, Bridges

markerText: Alarmed about draft resistance, the federal government deployed 800 troops to the Fishing Creek Valley in August 1864 to suppress the opposition. Peace Democrats suspected of Confederate sympathies were questioned at the Christian church near this site; 44 were arrested and imprisoned at Ft. Mifflin without access to civil courts. While most supported the Union, they disagreed with Pres. Lincoln's wartime policies. In 1866, the US Supreme Court declared military arrest & trial of civilians unconstitutional.
streetAddress: 90 Mill St. (PA 487), Benton, PA
markerCategories: Abraham Lincoln, Civil War, Forts, Government & Politics 19th Century, Military

markerText: A stockaded house used as a settler's refuge was situated here on the bank overlooking the river, 1778-80, when it was destroyed by the Indians. The land was later owned by James Wilson, an author of the Constitution.
streetAddress: Berwick Rd. near Naus Way, outside of Lime Ridge, ~6.5 miles NE of Bloomsburg
markerCategories: American Revolution, Forts, Government & Politics 18th Century, Military, Native American

markerText: Early in 1781 the McClure house was stockaded by the noted Indian fighter, Moses Van Campen, to protect settlers in this region after destruction of Fort Jenkins in 1780. Site on the north bank of the Susquehanna in present Bloomsburg.
streetAddress: US 11 at Fairgrounds / Ft. McClure Blvd., Bloomsburg
markerCategories: American Revolution, Early Settlement, Forts, Military, Native American

markerText: A stockade-type fort was built here in 1778 along Fishing Creek by Moses Van Campen. It served during the Revolution as a refuge against the Indians, by whom it was once attacked. Van Campen was the noted Indian scout of this region.
streetAddress: Lightstreet Rd. (PA 487) at Papermill/Central Rd., ~1.2 miles NE of Bloomsburg
markerCategories: American Revolution, Forts, Military, Native American

markerText: During WWII, 9,135 American Car & Foundry workers from the surrounding region produced 15,224 tanks for American and Allied Forces. The first US tank fabricated on an assembly line, the Stuart was favored for its speed and mobility and saw action in theaters of war on all continents. A.C.F. became the nation's largest producer of armor plate and was unique in having its own ballistics testing range. The plant was located here.
streetAddress: Third & Oak Sts., Berwick
markerCategories: Business & Industry, Labor, Military, Military Post-Civil War

markerText: Important path linking the many Indian settlements in the Wyoming Valley with Shamokin, now Sunbury. In 1742 Count Zinzendorf, organizer of Moravian missions, came this way after visiting the Shawnees at Wyoming.
streetAddress: US 11 at W Ft. McClure Blvd., at Fairgrounds, Bloomsburg
markerCategories: Native American, Religion, Transportation, Paths & Trails

markerText: Oldest college in continuous existence under the same name west of the Allegheny Mountains. Founded 1815. Chartered 1817. The college's first president, Timothy Alden, was architect of Bentley Hall, which became the center of administration.
streetAddress: N. Main St. (PA 86) at Sherman St., Meadville

markerText: Two blocks west from here is the home built in 1841 by Justice Henry Baldwin. Appointed to the U.S. Supreme Court in 1830. As a member of Congress in 1816 to 1822, he was an early protective tariff advocate.
streetAddress: Baldwin St. near Park Ave., Meadville
markerCategories: Government & Politics, Government & Politics 19th Century, Houses & Homesteads

markerText: Here in Crawford County on Sept. 9, 1842, direct primary elections were born when county Democrats used this system to nominate county offices. Republicans here began voting by this method in 1860. This "Crawford County System" gradually spread to other counties and to other states. By the early 20th century, it had become the nation's standard system for selecting party nominees for most offices.
streetAddress: Diamond Park Sq. / Main St. at the Courthouse, Meadville

markerText: Methodist missionary to India, south Asia, and the Philippines, 1859 to 1908. Upon retirement he lived in Meadville until his death in 1922. He is buried in Greendale Cemetery.
streetAddress: PA 77 at E end of Meadville

markerText: A founder and first president of Tidewater Pipe Co., est. 1878. He transformed the shipment of oil with a larger 6-inch pipe that covered greater distances than ever before. This pipeline was first to carry Pa. crude directly to coastal refineries. Benson lived here, 1872-88.
streetAddress: 603 N Perry St., Titusville

markerText: Between 1884 and 1915, this was a major health resort, founded upon the various mineral springs here. Dr. John H. Gray, who had discovered spring water on his farm, began prescribing and marketing it in 1884. By the early 1900s, some forty inns and resort hotels were operating, including the palatial Hotel Rider and the Riverside Inn. Passenger trains ran here daily. Ultimately, changes in medical practices ended this health spa's heyday.
streetAddress: at the Public Park, intersection of PA Routes 19 (Venango Ave.) & 86 (Main St.), Cambridge Springs
markerCategories: Business & Industry, Environment, Inns & Taverns, Railroads, Science & Medicine

markerText: Raised some 10 feet by a 23-mile "feeder" from Meadville, this lake was the vital source of water for the highest part of the canal, 4 miles west. Lake water and traffic flowed north to Erie, south to the Ohio River.
streetAddress: US 6 & 322 E of Conneaut Lake - Missing

markerText: Formed March 12, 1800 from Allegheny County. Meadville, in 1788, was the first permanent settlement in northwest Pennsylvania. In 1842 the nation's first direct primary was held here. Cradle of the oil and zipper industries. Named for Col. William Crawford.
streetAddress: County Courthouse, 903 Diamond Park, Meadville
markerCategories: Business & Industry, Early Settlement, Government & Politics, Government & Politics 19th Century, Oil & Gas

markerText: An event here in September 1880 led to the end of segregation by race in the state's public schools. At the South Ward schools, Elias Allen tried unsuccessfully to enroll his two children. He appealed to the Crawford County Court of Common Pleas, and Judge Pearson Church declared unconstitutional the 1854 state law mandating separate schools for Negro children. This law was amended, effective July 4, 1881, to prohibit such segregation.
streetAddress: S. Main St. across from Autumn Dr., at Second District School, Meadville
markerCategories: African American, Education, Government & Politics 19th Century

markerText: The first refinery in the Oil Creek Region for crude petroleum was built nearby in 1860. The first run of oil was made in 1861. Oil was first refined at Pittsburgh, about 1854, by Samuel Kier.
streetAddress: E Main St. (PA 27) near E Spring St., Titusville

markerText: The man who sank the first oil well is buried in Woodlawn Cemetery, and is commemorated by Niehaus's bronze figure of "The Driller." Drake Well is now a State park, a mile and a half south of Titusville.
streetAddress: PA 8 near Woodlawn Cemetery, Titusville

markerText: By this channel Conneaut Lake, raised 9 feet above normal level, fed water to the canal at its highest point, the junction of the Shenango and Conneaut Lines, about 2 miles west from here. The canal was in use 1844 to 1871.
streetAddress: PA 618 S of Conneaut Lake Park

markerText: Begun by the State, 1836, as part of a system of internal improvements. Completed 1843-44 by a private company. In use until 1871. Extended 105 miles from New Castle to Erie; French Creek Feeder joined it with Meadville.
streetAddress: US 6 & 322 E of Conneaut Lake (Missing)

markerText: Cut off from the rest of Pymatuning Swamp by a 3-mile bank, this became the 600-acre "Pymatuning Reservoir" of the canal, which lay at its western edge. Begun by the State, 1838; finished by the Erie Canal Co., 1843-44.
streetAddress: Liberty St. (US 322) between Cemetery Rd. & Crystal Lake Rd., E of Hartstown

markerText: Remains of the canal bed may be seen beside the railroad, below the bridge. Less than 2 miles away this Shenango Line, from New Castle, united with the Conneaut Line, from Erie. The entire canal was in use 1844-1871.
streetAddress: US 6 near Brooks Rd., just W of Conneaut Lake

markerText: Canal bed visible at foot of the slope, toward the railroad. Extended from Beaver Division Canal, at New Castle, to Erie; this part of the Shenango Line, north to Conneaut Lake, was completed in 1842, and in use until 1871.
streetAddress: PA 18 S of Adamsville at Mercer Co. line (Missing)

markerText: Part of the old channel lies near the highway. The Conneaut Line, from Erie to near Conneaut Lake, was begun by the State, 1838, and completed by the Erie Canal Company, 1843-44. Canal in use until 1871.
streetAddress: PA 18 N of Conneautville - Missing

markerText: The Riviere aux Boeufs of the French, renamed by George Washington in 1753. It had an important part in the French and Indian War and the settlement of northwestern Pennsylvania.
streetAddress: 200 W Adams St. (PA 173), near bridge, Cochranton, S of Meadville
markerCategories: Early Settlement, Environment, French & Indian War, George Washington

markerText: The canal visible beyond the field was built 1827-1834. Repaired in 1841, it carried water from French Creek to Conneaut Lake, reservoir for the Erie Extension canal, which operated between Erie and New Castle , 1844-71.
streetAddress: US 19 SW of Meadville and Eaglecrest Dr.

markerText: The canal bed beside the road is part of a channel constructed 1827-1834 to take water from Meadville to Conneaut Lake for the Erie Extension Canal. Two miles below here the Feeder crossed the creek by aqueduct.
streetAddress: US 322 S of Meadville

markerText: Noted oil historian, biographer of Lincoln, journalist, lived in this house about six years. She was graduated from the Titusville High School in 1875.
streetAddress: 324 E. Main St. (PA 27), Titusville

markerText: Photographer of oil industry from 1860, lived in this house. His thousands of views form an extraordinary record of an industry that began here. Born, Bury, England, in 1829; died Titusville, 1915.
streetAddress: 407 E. Main St. (PA 27), Titusville
markerCategories: Artists, Business & Industry, Ethnic & Immigration, Oil & Gas

markerText: John Brown of Ossawatomie and Harper's Ferry worked here as a tanner, 1825-35. The nearby house was then his home. His first wife and son are buried near.
streetAddress: John Brown Rd. (SR 1033), just S of PA 77, New Richmond
markerCategories: African American, Professions & Vocations, Underground Railroad

markerText: On the side road, a short distance south, are the remains of the tannery and home built by the noted abolitionist of Harper's Ferry fame. Here, he lived and worked from 1825 to 1835, employing as many as 15 men in producing leather.
streetAddress: PA 77, just W of John Brown Rd. (SR 1033), New Richmond
markerCategories: African American, Business & Industry, Underground Railroad, Houses & Homesteads

markerText: Renowned college football coach and name-sake for the sport's highest amateur honor, the Heisman Memorial Trophy. His innovations included legalizing the forward pass, the center snap, the scoreboard, and game quarters. Heisman promoted player safety by advocating gear improvements and rule revisions. A founder of the American Football Coaches Association, he grew up in Titusville and played football near his father's local oil cooperage.
streetAddress: adjacent to Carter Field, Central Ave. & Brown St., Titusville

markerText: Founded in 1788 by David Mead and other settlers from the Wyoming region. In 1800 made county seat. First direct primary in U.S. held here in 1842. Making of hookless fasteners was pioneered here.
streetAddress: US 6 & 19 N of Meadville (Missing)
markerCategories: Cities & Towns, Early Settlement, Government & Politics, Government & Politics 18th Century, Invention

markerText: Founded in 1788 by David Mead and other settlers from the Wyoming region. In 1800 made county seat. First direct primary in U.S. held here in 1842. Making of hookless fasteners was pioneered here.
streetAddress: S Main St. (US 322) S end of Meadville
markerCategories: Business & Industry, Cities & Towns, Early Settlement, Government & Politics 19th Century, Invention

markerText: Founded in 1788 by David Mead and other settlers from the Wyoming region. In 1800 made county seat. First direct primary in U.S. held here in 1842. Making of hookless fasteners was pioneered here.
streetAddress: US 6 & 322 W of Meadville (Missing)
markerCategories: Business & Industry, Cities & Towns, Early Settlement, Government & Politics 19th Century, Invention

markerText: Along this stream the first white explorers found Indians skimming surface oil. From 1859 to 1865, the center of oil production and its refining was along the banks of Oil Creek.
streetAddress: Smock Blvd. (PA 8) at Bloss St. and deadend of S Franklin St., Titusville
markerCategories: Business & Industry, Exploration, Native American, Oil & Gas

markerText: Drilled here in 1815 by Samuel Magaw and William Clark to reach brine, a frontier source of salt. When it was deepened by Daniel Shryock to 300 feet in 1819, oil was struck. Because of this unwanted byproduct, the well and salt works here were closed, 1821. This early yield of oil from a drilled well occurred 40 years before Edwin L. Drake's 1859 discovery near Titusville.
streetAddress: PA 198 near Redd's Corner Rd., Lawrence Corners, 1 mile E of Ohio line

markerText: Founded 1681 by William Penn as a Quaker Commonwealth. Birthplace of THE DECLARATION OF INDEPENDENCE and THE CONSTITUTION OF THE UNITED STATES.
streetAddress: US 6, 200 feet from state line (MISSING)
markerCategories: Government & Politics, Government & Politics 17th Century, William Penn

markerText: Founded 1681 by William Penn as a Quaker Commonwealth. Birthplace of THE DECLARATION OF INDEPENDENCE and THE CONSTITUTION OF THE UNITED STATES.
streetAddress: US 322, .4 miles from state line (MISSING)
markerCategories: Government & Politics, Government & Politics 17th Century, William Penn

markerText: Pa. State Senator, 1959-63, Lt. Governor, 1963-67, and Governor, 1967-71. The 1874 state charter was substantially reformed at a constitutional convention during his term. He promoted improvements in welfare, transportation, education, and environment, and public sector unionization. He became counsel to Vice President Rockefeller and chair of the US/China Committee. A WWII veteran and Allegheny College president, his first law office was here.
streetAddress: 911 Diamond Park, Meadville

markerText: Born a slave in Maryland in 1801, he escaped as a boy and about 1824 came to Meadville. A barber, he was long active in the Underground Railroad. His Arch Street house, since torn down, is estimated to have harbored some 500 runaway slaves prior to the Civil War.
streetAddress: Liberty & Arch Sts., next to Bethel AME Church, Meadville
markerCategories: African American, Professions & Vocations, Underground Railroad

markerText: First successful device for increasing the flow of oil by setting off an explosion deep in a well. It was publicly demonstrated in 1865. The nitroglycerin was made .4 mile south of here, along Hammond Run.
streetAddress: Smock Blvd. (PA 8), near Dutch Hill Rd., S end of Titusville

markerText: Here on August 5, 1936, the State's first rural electric pole was placed by the Northwestern Rural Electric Cooperative Association. Incorporated on April 30, 1936, this was Pennsylvania's first such cooperative. By 1941, thirteen more had been formed in this State.
streetAddress: PA 198 at Woodcock Creek Lake/Reservoir near dam end of parking lot, E of PA 86, Woodcock Twp.

markerText: The industry's first permanent oil exchange was organized in 1871 by producers, refiners, dealers, brokers. Starting in the American Hotel on this spot, it moved to other sites; returned here in a new three-story brick building, 1881. Dissolved 1897; building razed 1956.
streetAddress: Spring St. between Washington & Franklin, Titusville

markerText: A fine example of Greek Revival architecture. It was erected in 1835-36 at a cost of $3500, mostly given by Shippen and Huidekoper families. Planned by the builder of Fort Sumter, General George W. Cullum.
streetAddress: Main & Chestnut Sts., Meadville

markerText: Among the earliest (c. 1820) African American congregations located west of the Susquehanna River. The site of Underground Railroad activity. Abolitionists John Peck and John B. Vashon were members. A.M.E. national Bishops Daniel Payne and Wills Nazrey were associated with the church.
streetAddress: 131 E Pomfret St., Carlisle

markerText: Original log meeting house was erected 1737 near the Big Spring. Church was fully organized, October 1738. Present stone structure was built 1789, and in 1790 the trustees laid out Newville as a town on the church-owned glebe.
streetAddress: S. Corporation St. at church, Newville

markerText: Home of Gen. Ephraim Blaine, Commissary General of Revolutionary Army, stood on this site. George Washington was a guest here, Oct. 4-11, 1794, while mustering an armed force to quell Whiskey Rebellion in Western Pennsylvania.
streetAddress: S. Hanover St. between Pomfret & High Sts., Carlisle
markerCategories: American Revolution, George Washington, Military, Whiskey Rebellion

markerText: In 1755 supplies for Braddock's army were stored here in Edward Shippen's strong stone house "at the back Run." James Burd, the son-in-law of Shippen, opened a road to carry these supplies to the west. After Braddock's defeat remaining supplies were given to sufferers from Indian attacks.
streetAddress: W. King St. (US 11) between Spring & Morris Sts., Shippensburg

markerText: Founded in 1751 as the seat of Cumberland County. Historic old frontier town. Supplied a contingent for the first regiment of the Continental Army in 1775. March against the Whiskey Rebels began here, 1794.
streetAddress: Near Walnut Bottom Rd. & Washington St. intersection, at Thornwald Park entrance, Carlisle
markerCategories: Cities & Towns, Early Settlement, Military, Whiskey Rebellion

markerText: Founded in 1751 as the seat of Cumberland County. Historic old frontier town. Supplied a contingent for the first regiment of the Continental Army in 1775. March against the Whiskey Rebels began here, 1794.
streetAddress: N Hanover St. (US 11N), across from Church of God Home, east end of Carlisle
markerCategories: American Revolution, Cities & Towns, Early Settlement, Government & Politics, Whiskey Rebellion

markerText: Founded in 1751 as the seat of Cumberland County. Historic old frontier town. Supplied a contingent for the first regiment of the Continental Army in 1775. March against the Whiskey Rebels began here, 1794.
streetAddress: Ritner Hwy. (US11) near W Pomfret and Forbes Road marker, W end of Carlisle
markerCategories: American Revolution, Cities & Towns, Government & Politics, Whiskey Rebellion

markerText: Founded in 1751 as the seat of Cumberland County. Historic old frontier town. Supplied a contingent for the first regiment of the Continental Army in 1775. March against the Whiskey Rebels began here, 1794.
streetAddress: S Hanover St. (PA 34) S of Carlisle, between Noble Blvd. & Ridge St.
markerCategories: American Revolution, Cities & Towns, Government & Politics, Whiskey Rebellion

markerText: Founded in 1751 as the seat of Cumberland County. Historic old frontier town. Supplied a contingent for the first regiment of the Continental Army in 1775. March against the Whiskey Rebels began here, 1794.
streetAddress: Carlisle Sprgs. Rd. (PA 34) N end of Carlisle, at PA Turnpike overpass

markerText: Established 1757. Oldest Army Post in U.S. A powder magazine built by Hessian prisoners in 1777 survives. Burned by Confederates on July 1, 1863. Indian School, 1879-1918. Army Medical Field Service School, 1920-1946. Army War College since 1951.
streetAddress: US 11 opposite War College, NE end Carlisle

markerText: First fort authorized by Pennsylvania. Laid out by Gov. Morris, July, 1755, "in the middle of this town," on news of Braddock's defeat. Col. John Armstrong's headquarters till 1758. Called "Fort Lowther" by some later writers.
streetAddress: W. High St. between Pitt & Hanover Sts., Carlisle

markerText: This school was the model for a nation-wide system of boarding schools intended to assimilate American Indians into mainstream culture. Over 10,000 indigenous children attended the school between 1879 and 1918. Despite idealistic beginnings, the school left a mixed and lasting legacy, creating opportunity for some students and conflicted identities for others. In this cemetery are 186 graves of students who died while at Carlisle.
streetAddress: North side of Claremont Road, 50 feet East of the Carlisle Barracks entrance

markerText: Founded about 1762 by John Rigbie and Co. Operated after 1781 by Michael Ege, noted ironmaster of the period. Ruins of the charcoal furnace still stand.
streetAddress: PA 174 just E of Boiling Springs
markerCategories: Business & Industry, Coal, Furnaces, Iron & Steel

markerText: One of baseball's great pitchers. Bender played for the Philadelphia Athletics from 1903-14, helping them to win 5 pennants and 3 world championships. After winning 212 games over 16 seasons and becoming one of the first World Series stars, he was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1954. His mother was one-half Chippewa, and he attended Carlisle Indian Industrial School on this site from 1898-1901.
streetAddress: Indian Field, Carlisle Barracks, off U.S. 11, Carlisle
markerCategories: Baseball, Education, Native American, Sports & Recreation

markerText: The 1886 house and surroundings were an inspiration to this family. Brothers Frank and Eugene became prominent entomologists. Frank's nationally known conservationist sons, John and Frank, Jr., saved Yellowstone's grizzlies, popularized falconry, inspired the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act, and contributed to National Geographic. Newbery-winning daughter Jean Craighead George wrote nature books Julie of the Wolves and My Side of the Mountain.
streetAddress: 318 E Old York Rd. (Rt. 174), South Middleton Twp.
markerCategories: Environment, Government & Politics 20th Century, Professions & Vocations, Science & Medicine, Women, Writers

markerText: Formed January 27, 1750 from Lancaster County. Named for Cumberland County in England, it originally extended to Pennsylvania's western limits. Carlisle, county seat, was founded 1751. Crossed by major roads, county had a key role in westward migration.
streetAddress: Old Courthouse, High & Hanover Sts., Carlisle
markerCategories: Government & Politics, Government & Politics 18th Century, Transportation, Roads

markerText: Capt. William Hendricks led from nearby Cumberland County points a company of riflemen to Quebec, Canada. There they fought Dec. 31, 1775, at the side of Gen. Richard Montgomery. Hendricks was killed in action.
streetAddress: Willow Park, Market St. at 24th St., Camp Hill

markerText: Incorporated in 1831. Completed, Lemoyne to Chambersburg, 1837; eventually, Harrisburg to Virginia. For over 80 years, vital to Valley's economic life; merged into Pennsylvania R.R., 1919. Passenger Station, Stationmaster's House here, built in the 1860s.
streetAddress: 4 Strawberry Alley, Mechanicsburg

markerText: Inventor of a telephone for which he sought a patent in 1880. Claims contested by Bell Telephone, which won the court decision in 1888. Born in this village, July 14, 1827, where he developed his inventions; he removed in 1904 to Camp Hill, where he died November 2, 1911.
streetAddress: 155 Lake Rd. (SR 2033) at Eberly's Mill, 1 mile W of New Cumberland

markerText: An Underground Railroad agent from 1835 to 1847, when he was sued by a Maryland slave owner. He was ultimately fined $4,000 in 1852, in a case that drew wide attention. Kaufman had provided food and transportation to fugitive slaves passing through this area; his barn and a densely wooded area nearby furnished shelter. In 1845, Kaufman laid out the village of Boiling Springs, and he built his 301 Front Street home in 1880.
streetAddress: 301 Front Street, Boiling Springs
markerCategories: African American, Early Settlement, Underground Railroad

markerText: Dr. Benjamin Rush envisioned a new type of education for post-Revolutionary America, a useful education in the liberal arts. Rush, with the assistance of Col. John Montgomery of Carlisle, founded Dickinson College to prepare an engaged citizenry able to meet the leadership needs of the new nation. Chartered on September 9, 1783 and named for John Dickinson, the college was the first established west of the Susquehanna River.
streetAddress: W High St., near 74N intersection at campus, Carlisle

markerText: Oldest law school in Pennsylvania; founded in 1834 by the Honorable John Reed, eminent jurist, and author of "Pennsylvania Blackstone." Andrew Curtin, Civil War Governor, was one of earliest graduates.
streetAddress: S. College St. near South St. at Law School, Carlisle

markerText: This square was set apart by the Penns in 1751 for the Church of England; in continuous use since that time by St. John's Episcopal Church. In 1752, the first church building was erected.
streetAddress: NE corner, High & Hanover Sts., Carlisle

markerText: The farthest north attained by any organized body of the Confederate Army of General Robert E. Lee was reached here at the farm of Joseph Miller on the morning of June 28, 1863. Hearing that Sterrett's Gap was occupied by Union troops these outposts returned to their command at Carlisle. From these hills the tide of Confederate invasion receded destined never to return.
streetAddress: PA 34 (E side), .7 mile N of Carlisle Springs

markerText: Oldest public building in Carlisle; erection begun, 1757. Here colonists met in 1774 to declare for independence, and George Washington worshipped, 1794. Congregation organized at Meeting House Springs in 1734.
streetAddress: NW corner, High & Hanover Sts., Carlisle

markerText: To capture Fort Duquesne, General Forbes marched an army, in 1758, from his main base at Carlisle to the Forks of the Ohio. He followed, as closely as he could with army wagons, the Raystown Indian and Traders Path, widened by axemen under Colonel Henry Bouquet.
streetAddress: Ritner Hwy. (US 11), near W Pomfret and Carlisle marker, just W of Carlisle
markerCategories: French & Indian War, Military, Transportation, Roads

markerText: At Shippensburg, the Raystown Path forked: one branch led directly west over three steep mts. to Burnt Cabins; the other, taken by General Forbes to avoid heavy grades, went south round Parnells Knob to Fort Loudon, crossing the Tuscarora Mountain at Cowan Gap.
streetAddress: US 11, 1 mile NE of Shippensburg
markerCategories: French & Indian War, Military, Transportation, Roads

markerText: Remains of breastworks, at Eighth and Ohio Streets, built before the battle of Gettysburg, to oppose the expected Southern drive on Harrisburg. June 29, 1863, a few Confederate scouts neared here but withdrew.
streetAddress: Ohio St. at W Park Ave., Lemoyne

markerText: Remains of breastworks built in June 1863 to oppose an expected attack on Harrisburg by Confederate troops. Site then known as Hummel's Heights. Fort was named for General Couch, Commander, Eastern Pennsylvania Military Department.
streetAddress: Indiana Ave., betw. 8th St. & West Park, Lemoyne

markerText: Named for Gov. R.H. Morris, and built by local settlers under the supervision of James Burd after Braddock's defeat in July, 1755. Later garrisoned by provincial troops commanded by Hugh Mercer. The fort site, long marked by the soldiers' well, lies a block to the north on Burd Street.
streetAddress: King (US 11) & Queen Sts., Shippensburg

markerText: Erected in November 1755 by Col. James Burd, and used as one of the chain of forts to protect the frontiers during the period of Indian hostility following the defeat of General Edward Braddock.
streetAddress: Shippensburg
markerCategories: Forts, French & Indian War, Military, Native American

markerText: On a 116-acre tract here stood the model farm created 1857-67 by this agricultural reformer. Watts was the first president of the Pennsylvania Agricultural Society, 1851; a founder of the Farmers' High School (now Penn State); and U.S. Commissioner of Agriculture, 1871-76. The farm remained until 1988. Its site selection, layout, and building designs reflected Watts's pioneering ideas on farm efficiency.
streetAddress: Ritner Hwy. (US 11) & Shearer Dr. at entrance to Watts Bus. Park, W of Carlisle
markerCategories: Agriculture, Education, Environment, Government & Politics, Professions & Vocations

markerText: "Hero of Kittanning," Revolutionary officer, member of Continental Congress, County Judge, lived in a house on this site. Died at Carlisle, 1795. Buried in Old Graveyard, two blocks south.
streetAddress: NE corner, High & Bedford Sts., Carlisle

markerText: Early Carlisle physician, member of Provincial Convention, Revolutionary officer, commander at Fort Pitt, occupied house that stood on this site before 1800.
streetAddress: SE corner, High & Bedford Sts., Carlisle
markerCategories: American Revolution, Government & Politics 18th Century, Military, Professions & Vocations, Science & Medicine

markerText: Here George Washington reviewed militia from Pennsylvania and New Jersey, rendezvoused at Carlisle, October 1794, before marching to the Western part of State to quell the Whiskey Rebellion.
streetAddress: W High & West Sts., Carlisle
markerCategories: American Revolution, George Washington, Military, Whiskey Rebellion

markerText: On June 28, 1863, General Richard Ewell received orders from Robert E. Lee to move Ewell's southern troops out of Carlisle and on to Gettysburg. By June 29th two divisions of Ewell's troops marched over this road through Mt. Holly Springs, York Springs, and Heidlersburg towards Gettysburg.
streetAddress: PA 34, .3 mile S of Carlisle near I-81

markerText: Farthest advance of a body of Confederate troops toward Harrisburg. Southern units under General A.G. Jenkins of Ewell's Corps reached Oyster Point on June 28, 1863. On the next day defending militia faced them here in a skirmish in which both sides suffered casualties.
streetAddress: 3025 Market St., Camp Hill

markerText: This campaign's northernmost engagement, known as the Battle of Sporting Hill, occurred just north and west of here, June 30, 1863. The 22nd & 37th New York Militia Regiments, along with Landis's Philadelphia Battery, fought in defense of Harrisburg against the 16th & 36th Virginia Cavalry units. Afterward the Confederates withdrew to Carlisle, leaving some 16 dead. Reported wounded were 11 Union soldiers; 20-30 Confederates.
streetAddress: 5002 Carlisle Pike, Hampden Township (@ Gilligan's)

markerText: Gen. J.E.B. Stuart's Southern cavalry arrived July 1, 1863, by Dover and Dillsburg. Finding Ewell had left the day before, Stuart burned the U.S. Barracks and left for Gettysburg, where the battle had begun.
streetAddress: PA 74 just E of Carlisle near I-81

markerText: June 27, 1863, Gen. Ewell's Confederate army, marching over this road toward Harrisburg, reached Carlisle; Jenkins' cavalry went on to reconnoiter. On June 29, Lee ordered Ewell to join the main army at Cashtown.
streetAddress: Walnut Bottom Rd. (SR 3023), .5 mile SW of Carlisle near I-81

markerText: Confederate General Albert G. Jenkins and his staff occupied this house, June 28-30, 1863. His brigade, a part of General Ewell's Corps, had entered Mechanicsburg to reconnoiter the approaches to Harrisburg with a view toward a June 30 attack. The troops withdrew from here on the 30th, however, having been ordered to Gettysburg in advance of the battle there. This house, owned at that time by John Rupp, was built in 1787 by his grandfather, Jonas Rupp.
streetAddress: 5115 East Trindle Road, Mechanicsburg

markerText: In 1753, Benjamin Franklin stayed at inn on this site while he, Richard Peters, and Isaac Norris treated with Indians. Hamilton and Knox, members of Washington's cabinet, lodged here in 1794.
streetAddress: S. Hanover St. between Pomfret & High Sts., Carlisle
markerCategories: Business & Industry, George Washington, Inns & Taverns, Native American

markerText: Pennsylvania's capital since 1812. As Harris' Ferry, was settled a century before by John Harris Sr. Laid out as a town in 1785 by John Harris Jr. For over 200 years a center of travel, trade, and historic events.
streetAddress: Front St., at Market St., Wormleysburg
markerCategories: Cities & Towns, Early Settlement, Government & Politics

markerText: Early example of a wrought iron bowstring arch truss bridge. Patented in 1869 by Joseph G. Henszey and built that year by the Continental Bridge Co. of Philadelphia, this bridge was part of a proliferation of bridges following the Civil War. In Lehigh County it crossed Trout Creek in Slatington and then was moved in 1900 to span the Ontelaunee Creek at Wanamaker. In 2002, the bridge was moved to Summerdale to carry pedestrian traffic.
streetAddress: Valley Road on edge of campus of Central Pennsylania College, Enola
markerCategories: Business & Industry, Iron & Steel, Transportation, Bridges

markerText: Site of the College that was chartered in 1857, and named for Washington Irving, a trustee. First women's college in Pennsylvania to grant degrees in arts and sciences. It closed in 1929.
streetAddress: E. Main St. (Pa. 641) near Filbert St., Mechanicsburg

markerText: Early Carlisle lawyer, and representative to Continental Congress, occupied house that stood on this site. He was a signer of the Declaration of Independence, and one of the framers of the Constitution of U.S.
streetAddress: SW corner, High & Pitt Sts., Carlisle
markerCategories: Government & Politics, Government & Politics 18th Century, Professions & Vocations

markerText: Distinguished jurist and author of legal books, lived in this house from about 1820 until his death, 1853; Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania for 24 years of his 37 years membership.
streetAddress: E. High St. between Hanover & Bedford Sts., Carlisle
markerCategories: Government & Politics, Government & Politics 19th Century, Professions & Vocations, Writers

markerText: Two-term Governor of Pennsylvania, 1867-73. Major General in Civil War. Colonel, 2nd Pa. Regiment in Mexican War. Governor, Kansas Territory. First postmaster & first mayor of San Francisco. His home was a block east at 308 Market Street.
streetAddress: 3rd & Bridge Sts., New Cumberland
markerCategories: Civil War, Government & Politics, Government & Politics 19th Century, Governors, Military

markerText: Governor of Pennsylvania, 1835-1839, lies buried in this cemetery. Born, 1780, in Berks County; died, 1869, at Carlisle. He was noted for having put into practical operation the law of 1834, which established the public school system.
streetAddress: US 11, 6 miles SW of Carlisle
markerCategories: Education, Government & Politics, Government & Politics 19th Century, Governors

markerText: Grist mill built about 1763 by William Laughlin. Owned by his family until 1896. Preserved by Ethel T. McCarthy. The oldest such structure remaining in this region.
streetAddress: Carlisle Newvile Rd. (PA 641) & Laughlin Mill Rd. at E end of Newville

markerText: Burial ground for slaves and free blacks since the early 19th century and site of Shippensburg's first African American church, established 1830s. Edward Shippen Burd granted the land to Shippensburg's African American community in 1842. It was the only public cemetery open to African Americans in the area until the late 20th century. Graves of veterans from the Civil War to the Vietnam conflict include those of twenty-six Civil War soldiers.
streetAddress: 100 block of N Queen St., Shippensburg

markerText: For a short time in 1776, Major Andre and Lt. Despard, British prisoners of war, were detained in a tavern that stood on this site. Some years later, after an exchange and recapture, Andre was executed as a spy.
streetAddress: S. Hanover St. between South & Pomfret Sts., Carlisle

markerText: Maj., 7th U.S. Cavalry at Battle of Little Big Horn, 1876; Lt. Col. Geo. A. Custer & the troops he led were killed, but Reno & most of his command survived. During the civil war, Reno helped defend this region against Confederate invaders. His farm was near here.
streetAddress: 3rd & Reno Sts., New Cumberland

markerText: Eminent poet, editor, essayist, and teacher. Her independent spirit and keen eye for detail distinguished her life and work. Moore won the Pulitzer Prize for Literature, the Bollingen Prize in Poetry, and the National Book Award. She lived here (1896-1916).
streetAddress: 343 N Hanover Street, Carlisle

markerText: Founded 1738 by pioneer Scotch-Irish Presbyterians. Until 1781, the church was at the old cemetery which is about one-tenth mile NW from here. Present church built, 1847; parsonage built, 1855.
streetAddress: SR 4001 (old PA 696), 2.6 miles N of Shippensburg

markerText: Mary "Ludwig" Hays McCauley, known as "Molly Pitcher," heroine at Battle of Monmouth, is buried in Old Graveyard just east of here. In this burial ground are graves of many distinguished citizens.
streetAddress: S. Hanover St. between Walnut & South Sts., Carlisle

markerText: "Widow Piper's Tavern," used for Cumberland County court-sessions, 1750-51, until a court house was erected at Carlisle, the county seat. The house is now the home of the Shippensburg Civic Club.
streetAddress: E King St. (US 11) & N Queen St., Shippensburg
markerCategories: Buildings & Architecture, Government & Politics, Government & Politics 18th Century, Inns & Taverns

markerText: Scots-Irish immigrant who amassed wealth as a merchant and slave trader and contributed the modern equivalent of several million dollars to the Revolutionary War. Believing control of the West pivotal to America's future, he negotiated to open routes along the Mississippi River enabling the delivery of vital arms and supplies and financed the Illinois Campaign. Massive debt from the war led to imprisonment and loss of many holdings. He lived here from 1792 to 1806.
streetAddress: 6395 Carlisle Pike, Mechanicsburg

markerText: The Mount Jackson or Potato Point School, originally built in 1865, is an authentically reconstructed one-room schoolhouse. It was relocated here in 1969 by alumni and friends of Shippensburg State College to preserve part of America's educational heritage.
streetAddress: N Earl St./Newburg Rd. (PA 696) at the University, Shippensburg

markerText: Present building erected in 1798 by a Reformed congregation. Half-interest obtained in 1806 by a Lutheran congregation; in joint use until 1866. Kept in its original form; used for special services.
streetAddress: at site, PA 641 (Trindle Rd.) at St. John's Rd., W of Camp Hill

markerText: Present building erected in 1798 by a Reformed congregation. Half-interest obtained in 1806 by a Lutheran congregation; in joint use until 1866. Kept in its original form; used annually by St. John's Lutheran. A half-mile away.
streetAddress: Carlisle Pike (SR 1010) at St. John's Rd., 1.2 miles W. of Camp Hill

markerTitle: Pine Grove Furnace POW Interrogation Camp
markerText: During WWII, the US War Dept. operated this secret facility a mile north along Michaux Rd., one of three such sites in the US. Military intelligence relating to topics such as weaponry development and Axis operations was gained from thousands of German and Japanese prisoners. Originally a farm serving the iron industry, 1785-1919, the site was converted to Civilian Conservation Corps Camp S-51-PA, 1933-42. After the war it became church Camp Michaux, 1946-72.
streetAddress: Pine Grove Rd. (Rt. 233) & Michaux Rd., Cooke Twp.
markerCategories: Agriculture, Furnaces, Government & Politics 20th Century, Iron & Steel, Military Post-Civil War, Religion

markerText: On August 23, 1752, Scottish Covenanter Presbyterians held their first recorded Communion in the New World here at Joseph and Elizabeth Junkin's farm. A scattered community of 250 worshippers attended this nine-hour outdoor service at the "Junkin Tent" on America's frontier. Rev. John Cuthbertson, the first Reformed Presbyterian missionary in America, presided over the gathering, which contributed to the establishment of the denomination.
streetAddress: Carlisle Pike (Rt. 11), south(west) bound, near N Locust Point Rd., New Kingstown

markerText: Legislator and official lived here in Lowther Manor on land conveyed by the Penns in 1771. At the state's 1787 convention to ratify the U.S. Constitution, Whitehill led the Anti-federalist minority; he presented amendments later embodied in the Bill of Rights. A drafter of the 1776 state constitution, he served terms with both the legislature and executive council; was in Congress, 1805-13.
streetAddress: 1903 Market St., Camp Hill
markerCategories: Government & Politics, Government & Politics 18th Century, Mansions & Manors, William Penn

markerText: Founded 1730 by Edward Shippen. Second oldest town in the state west of the Susquehanna River. Important community on colonial frontier. Temporary seat of Cumberland Co., whose first courts were held here in 1750-51.
streetAddress: E King St. (US 11) near Walnut Bottom Rd. (Rt. 174), E end of Shippensburg

markerText: Settled about 1733. Laid out and named for Edward Shippen, 1703-1781, merchant, mayor and justice of Philadelphia, later a resident of Lancaster, paymaster in the Forbes Expedition, a founder and trustee of Princeton University. Grandson of Edward Shippen (1639-1712) who was the host of William Penn, mayor and merchant of Philadelphia, speaker of the assembly, president of the provincial council andÂ chief justice of Pennsylvania.
streetAddress: King St. (US 11) & Prince St., on Vigilant Hose Co. #1 bldg., Shippensburg

markerText: Founded 1734 on land of James Silver by Scotch-Irish Presbyterians, earliest settlers of the Cumberland Valley. Present church built in 1783, restored in 1928 to its original style, and still used for worship.
streetAddress: 444 Silver Spring Rd., at church, S of Carlisle Pk. (US 11), Mechanicsburg

markerText: Built about 1792. It extended from Michael Simpson's Ferry on the Susquehanna to Carlisle, following, at this point, a course later known as Simpson St. Used by many persons traveling to western part of State.
streetAddress: Simpson St. near Walnut St., Mechanicsburg

markerText: In 1779, Father Charles Sewall, S.J., took title to a lot here. Log structure built 1784; brick edifice in 1806. Present church erected 1893 by Father Henry G. Ganss. Adjacent is St. Katherine's Hall, built by Mother Katherine Drexel, 1901, for Catholics at Carlisle Indian School.
streetAddress: 140 E. Pomfret St. at church, Carlisle

markerText: The Pennsylvania State Police Training School, first of its kind in the nation, was established here in 1920 at the old Big Spring Hotel, which stood nearby. In 1923 the location of the school was transferred to Hershey, in Dauphin County.
streetAddress: Walnut St. near Big Spring Ave., Newville

markerText: Located at this site, James Bell's tavern was a meeting place for Anti-Federalists. Members of the Anti-Federalist movement from the Cumberland frontier, led by Robert Whitehill, met in 1788 to oppose the US Constitution, because it lacked guarantees for individual liberties and states' rights. They demanded amendments. This meeting is linked to the adoption of the Bill of Rights and the founding of the Democratic-Republican Party.
streetAddress: Carlisle Pike (Rt. 11) at Louis Blvd., Silver Spring Twp., ~1 mile E of I-81
markerCategories: Government & Politics, Government & Politics 18th Century, Inns & Taverns

markerText: On this lot Thomas Butler had his home and gunshop about 1764; the latter still stands to the rear. Butler and five sons, all officers, served in the Revolution. Often referred to as the "Fighting Butlers."
streetAddress: W. High St. between Pitt & West Sts., Carlisle

markerText: The first battalion in the colonies authorized by Congress, June 1775. Totaling nine companies, it was initially led by Col. William Thompson of Carlisle. Later the organization became the First Pennsylvania Continental Regiment.
streetAddress: E. South St. at Old Graveyard, Carlisle (MISSING)

markerText: Oldest public building in Mechanicsburg. Built in 1825 on land given by Martin Rupp. As provided in the charter, it has been used by many religious sects on payment of small fee.
streetAddress: 39 E. Main St. (PA 641) at church, Mechanicsburg

markerText: With its excellent railroad connection, this became the site of the Great Grangers' Interstate Picnic Exhibition, founded 1874 by Robert H. Thomas of the Pennsylvania State Grange. A week's attendance at this annual event was estimated at 100,000 or more by the 1890's. The John Williams House, built about 1799, is nearby.
streetAddress: Williams Grove Rd. (SR 2011), .5 mile S of Wms. Grove Park

markerText: On February 22, 1861, while journeying to Washington for his Inauguration, Lincoln stopped at the Jones House, on this site. From the portico of the hotel, he addressed a large crowd gathered in Market Square.
streetAddress: S. Market Square (E side), Harrisburg
markerCategories: Abraham Lincoln, Government & Politics, Government & Politics 19th Century

markerText: North at the head of Beaver Creek, Joseph Barnett's log house was a frontier refuge in 1756-63 against Indians raiding the frontier. His son William was stolen by Indians in 1756 and not recovered until 1763 by Col. Henry Bouquet.
streetAddress: Pa. 39, 1.3 miles E of Linglestown near intersection with Piketown Rd.
markerCategories: Early Settlement, Forts, French & Indian War, Military, Native American
